antigonus: <entryFree id="n2864" type="main" key="Anti^go^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭgŏnus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)anti/gonos</foreign>. <sense id="n2864.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of several kings after Alexander the Great.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2864.1" n="A" level="2"> Antigonus I., <hi rend="ital">father of Demetrius Poliorcetes</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:5:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Eum. 5, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:14:48" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 14, 48</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:13" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 13</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2864.2" n="B" level="2"> Antigonus Gonatas, <hi rend="ital">son of Demetrius Poliorcetes</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:17:1" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 17, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:24:1 al" default="NO">24, 1 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n2864.3" n="C" level="2"> Antigonus Doson, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 54</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:28:3" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 28, 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2864.4" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Of other persons.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2864.5" n="A" level="2"> Antigonus <hi rend="ital">of Cymœ</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a writer on Agriculture</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:1:8" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 1, 8</bibl>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:1:1:9" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 1, 1, 9</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2864.6" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A plastic artist</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 8, 19, § 84</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2864.7" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A messenger of king Deiotarus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:15:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Deiot. 15, 41</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2864.8" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A Roman freedman</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 33</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antilibanus: <entryFree id="n2865" type="main" key="Anti^li^ba^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭlĭbănus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)antili/banos</foreign>, <sense id="n2865.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a mountain range in Phœnicia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">opposite to Libanus</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Jebel esh-Shurky</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 2, 16</bibl>; cf. Mann. Phoen. 270 sq.</sense></entryFree>
antilochus: <entryFree id="n2866" type="main" key="Anti^lo^chus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭlŏchus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)anti/loxos</foreign>, <sense id="n2866.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a son of Nestor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">slain by Hector before Troy</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:9:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 9, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 1, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:10:253" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 10, 253</bibl>. <cb n="ANTI" /></sense></entryFree>
antimachus: <entryFree id="n2867" type="main" key="Anti^ma^chus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭmăchus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)anti/maxos</foreign>. <sense id="n2867.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A Greek poet of Colophon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a contemporary of Socrates and Plato</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and author of a Thebaid</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:51:191" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 51, 191</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:95:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 95, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:32:45" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 32, 45</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2867.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A centaur slain by Cœneus in the contest with the Lapithœ</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:460" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 460</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n2867.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A son of Ægyptus</hi>, murdered by his bride, Idæa, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 170" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 170</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2867.3" n="IV" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A statuary</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 8, 19, § 86</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antimetabole: <entryFree id="n2868" type="greek" key="anti^me^ta^bo^le_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antĭmĕtăbŏlē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ntimetabolh/</foreign>, a rhet. fig., <sense id="n2868.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a reciprocal interchange</hi>, in Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 28, 39</bibl>, called commutatio, e. g.: <cit><quote lang="la">non ut edam vivo, sed ut vivam edo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 2, 21, p. 81</bibl></cit> Lind. (in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:3:85" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 3, 85</bibl>, written as Greek, Halm).</sense></entryFree>
antinomia: <entryFree id="n2869" type="greek" key="anti^no^mi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antĭnŏmĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ntinomi/a</foreign>, <sense id="n2869.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a contradiction between laws</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:7:1" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7, 7, 1</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:10:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 7, 10, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:3:6:45" default="NO">3, 6, 45</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antiochea: <entryFree id="n2870" type="main" key="Anti^o^che_a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭŏchēa</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭŏchīa</orth> (like Alexandrēa, Alexandrīa, q. v.; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 588</bibl> P., and Ochsn. Eclog. 143), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)antio/xeia</foreign>, <sense id="n2870.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Antioch.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2870.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of several cities.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2870.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The most distinguished is that founded by Seleucus Nicator</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and named after his father Antiochus; the chief town of Syria</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the Orontes</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Antakia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:15:4" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 15, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Arch. 3, 4</bibl>; cf. Mann. Syr. 363.— </sense><sense id="n2870.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A town in Caria</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the Mœander;</hi> also called <foreign lang="greek">*i*iuqo/polis</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:108" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 29, 29, § 108</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2870.4" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">In Mesopotamia</hi>, afterwards called <hi rend="ital">Edessa</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 24, 21, § 86</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2870.5" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">In Mygdonia</hi> (Mesopotamia), <foreign lang="greek">*)antio/xeia h\ *mugdonikh/</foreign>, now <hi rend="ital">Nisibin</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 13, 16, § 42</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n2870.6" n="E" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">In Macedonia; its inhabitants</hi>, Antiochienses, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 10, 17, § 35</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2870.7" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The province of Syria</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in which Antiochia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the Orontes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">was situated</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 12, 13, § 66</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:11:12" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 1, 11, 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antiochensis: <entryFree id="n2871" type="main" key="Anti^o^chensis1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭŏchensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Antiochia</etym>, <sense id="n2871.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Antiochia</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">plebs,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 7</bibl></cit>.—Hence, in <number>plur.</number>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭŏchenses</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Antiochia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:102" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 102</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 80</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 82 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2872" type="hapax" key="Anti^o^chensis2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭŏchensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Antiochus</etym>, <sense id="n2872.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to King Antiochus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecunia,</quote> <trans><tr>received from him</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:3:7:1" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 3, 7, 1</bibl></cit> (cf. 2. Antiochenus).</sense></entryFree>
antiochenus: <entryFree id="n2873" type="main" key="Anti^o^che_nus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭŏchēnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Antiochia</etym>, <sense id="n2873.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Antiochia</hi>: ager, Ven. Fort. 8, 5 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2874" type="main" key="Anti^o^che_nus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭŏchēnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Antiochus</etym>, <sense id="n2874.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to King Antiochus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecunia,</quote> <trans><tr>received from him</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:4:18" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 4, 18</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:19" default="NO">7, 19</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi> (cf. 2. Antiochensis).</sense></entryFree>
antiocheus: <entryFree id="n2875" type="main" key="Anti^o^che_us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭŏchēus</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-īus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)antio/xeios</foreign>, <sense id="n2875.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the philosopher Antiochus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ista Antiochea contemnit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 36, 115</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 13, 19</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antiochinus: <entryFree id="n2876" type="main" key="Anti^o^chi_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭŏchīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Antiochus</etym>. <sense id="n2876.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Of King Antiochus Magnus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">bellum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:11:7:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 11, 7, 17</bibl></cit>; cf. Fasti Capitol. Baiter, p. xli.—</sense><sense id="n2876.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the philosopher Antiochus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the founder of the fifth Academy</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:8:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 8, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antiochius: <entryFree id="n2877" type="main" key="Anti^o^chi_us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭŏchīus</orth>, v. Antiocheus.</entryFree>
antiochus: <entryFree id="n2878" type="main" key="Anti^o^chus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭŏchus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)anti/oxos</foreign>. <sense id="n2878.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of several Syrian kings</hi>, <hi rend="ital">among whom Antiochus Magnus was most distinguished</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on account of his war with the Romans</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:33:13" default="NO" valid="yes">33, 13</bibl> sq. al.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Hann. 2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Hann. 2, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:18:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 18, 75</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 1, 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:chapter=27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:13 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Deiot. 13 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n2878.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of an Academic philosopher</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a teacher of Cicero and Brutus</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 43, 132</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:3:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 3, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:91:315" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 91, 315</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antiopa: <entryFree id="n2879" type="main" key="Anti^o^pa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭŏpa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)antio/ph</foreign>. <sense id="n2879.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A daughter of Nycteus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wife of Lycus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king of Thebes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mother of Amphion and Zethus.</hi> She was bound to the neck of a bull by Dirce, whom Lycus had married, but was released by her sons, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 7" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 7</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2879.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of a tragedy of Pacuvius</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:2:4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 2, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:1:77" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 1, 77</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antipater: <entryFree id="n2880" type="main" key="Anti^pa^ter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭpăter</orth>, <itype>tri</itype> (later form, ANTIPATRVS, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 4727</bibl>), <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)anti/patros</foreign>. <sense id="n2880.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">One of the generals and successors of Alexander the Great</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the father of Cassander</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:11:7" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 11, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:11:12" default="NO">11, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:13:5 al" default="NO">13, 5 al.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:14:48" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 14, 48</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2880.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">His grandson</hi>, <hi rend="ital">son of Cassander</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and son-in-law of Lysimachus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:16:1" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 16, 1</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2880.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of several philosophers.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2880.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Of a Cyrenaic</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:37:107" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 37, 107</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2880.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Of a Stoic</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:12:51" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 12, 51</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 6, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 20</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2880.5" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Of a contemporary of Cicero</hi>, <hi rend="ital">from Tyre</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:24:86" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 24, 86</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2880.6" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A distinguished lawyer</hi>, <hi rend="ital">friend of the orator L. Crassus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:12:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 12, 54</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:26:102" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 26, 102</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:2 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 1, 2 al.</bibl> <cb n="ANTI" /></sense></entryFree>
antipathes: <entryFree id="n2881" type="greek" key="anti^pa^the_s1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antĭpăthēs</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ntipaqh/s</foreign> (serving as remedy for suffering), <sense id="n2881.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a black kind of coral used as a preventive of witchcraft</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 10, 54, § 145</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2882" type="main" key="anti^pa^the^s2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antĭpăthĕs</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ntipaqe/s</foreign>, <sense id="n2882.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a charm against pain</hi>, Lael. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Mag. 30</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antipathia: <entryFree id="n2883" type="greek" key="anti^pa^thi_a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antĭpăthīa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ntipa/qeia</foreign>, <sense id="n2883.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the natural aversion of two things to each other</hi>, <hi rend="ital">antipathy</hi> (opp. concordia), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 4, 15, § 59</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 20, 4, 13, § 28</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:67 al" default="NO" valid="yes">24, 9, 41, § 67 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
antipatria: <entryFree id="n2884" type="main" key="Anti^pa_^tri^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭpā^trĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)antipatri/a</foreign>, <sense id="n2884.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Macedonia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the borders of Illyria</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 27</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antiphates: <entryFree id="n2885" type="main" key="Anti^pha^tes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭphătes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)antifa/ths</foreign>. <sense id="n2885.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A king of the Lœstrygones</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who sunk the fleet of the Greeks returning from Troy with Ulysses</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and devoured one of his companions</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:234 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 234 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:14:20" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 14, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:531" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 531</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2885.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A son of Sarpedon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">slain by Turnus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:696" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 696</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antipherna: <entryFree id="n2886" type="greek" key="anti^pherna"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antĭpherna</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nti/ferna</foreign>, <sense id="n2886.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the return-present which the bridegroom brought to the bride</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 5, 3, 20</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antiphon: <entryFree id="n2887" type="main" key="Anti^pho_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭphōn</orth>, <itype>ōntis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)antifw=n</foreign>. <sense id="n2887.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A renowned sophist of Rhamnus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a contemporary of Socrates</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:12:47" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 12, 47</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:3:1:11" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 3, 1, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:10:22" default="NO">12, 10, 22</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2887.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of an interpreter of dreams</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:20" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 20</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 51</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antiphrasis: <entryFree id="n2888" type="greek" key="anti^phra^sis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antĭphrăsis</orth> (better written as Gr.), <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">anti/frasis</foreign>, <sense id="n2888.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the use of a word in a sense opposite to its proper meaning;</hi> as, <hi rend="ital">lucus</hi>, quod minime luceat, <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 458</bibl> P.; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 247</bibl> P. al.</sense></entryFree>
antipodes: <entryFree id="n2889" type="greek" key="anti^po^des"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antĭpŏdes</orth>, <itype>um</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nti/podes</foreign>, <sense id="n2889.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the antipodes</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 3, 23</bibl>; Aug. Civ. Dei, 16, 9; <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 6, 532</bibl>; hence ironic. of <hi rend="ital">banqueters</hi> who turn night to day, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 122" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 122</bibl> (in <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 39, 123</bibl>, written as Greek).</sense></entryFree>
antipolis: <entryFree id="n2890" type="main" key="Anti^po^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭpŏlis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)anti/polis</foreign>. <sense id="n2890.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A city in Gaul</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Antibes</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 4, 5, § 35</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:5" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 5</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭpŏlĭtānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">from Antipolis</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">thynni,</quote> <trans><tr>found in that region</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:13:103" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 13, 103</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:4:89" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 4, 89</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2890.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An old settlement in Latium</hi>, <hi rend="ital">afterwards Janiculum</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 9, § 68</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antiptosis: <entryFree id="n2891" type="greek" key="antipto_sis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antiptōsis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nti/ptwsis</foreign>, a gram. fig., <sense id="n2891.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the putting of one case for another</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 1, 577</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 283</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">6, 727</bibl>; 10, 653; 11, 56 al.</sense></entryFree>
antiquarius: <entryFree id="n2892" type="main" key="anti_qua_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antīquārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>antiquus</etym>, <sense id="n2892.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to antiquity.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2892.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Adj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ars,</quote> <trans><tr>the art of reading and copying ancient MSS</tr>.,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> Ep. ad Flor. 5, 1</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n2892.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">antīquārĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> </sense><sense id="n2892.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">One that is fond of or employs himself about antiquities</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an antiquarian</hi>, <hi rend="ital">antiquary</hi> (post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">nec quemquam adeo antiquarium puto, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Or. 21</bibl></cit>; * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:86" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 86</bibl>.—Also * <orth extent="full" lang="la">antī-quārĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">she that is fond of antiquity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a female antiquarian</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:454" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 454</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n2892.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">One that understands reading and copying ancient MSS.</hi>, Cod. Th. 4, 8, 2; <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Ep. 16 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
antiquatio: <entryFree id="n2893" type="hapax" key="anti_qua_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antīquātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>antiquo</etym>; in judicial lang., <sense id="n2893.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an abrogating</hi>, <hi rend="ital">annulling</hi>, <hi rend="ital">repealing</hi>: poenarum, Cod. Th. 6, 55, 4.</sense></entryFree>
antique: <entryFree id="n2894" type="main" key="anti_que_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antīquē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. antiquus.</entryFree>
antiquitas: <entryFree id="n2895" type="main" key="anti_qui^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antīquĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>antiquus</etym>, <sense id="n2895.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the quality of being</hi> antiquus, <hi rend="ital">age</hi>, <hi rend="ital">antiquity</hi> (class., but only in prose). </sense><sense id="n2895.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">antiquitas generis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,007:14:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Font. 14, 31</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Milt. 1, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non vestra (urbs) haec est, quae gloriabatur a diebus pristinis in antiquitate suā?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:23:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Isa. 23, 7</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2895.2" n="II" level="1"> Spec., <hi rend="ital">ancient time</hi>, <hi rend="ital">antiquity.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2895.3" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">fabulae ab ultimā antiquitate repetitae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:20:65" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 20, 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">habet ut in aetatibus auctoritatem senectus, sic in exemplis antiquitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:50:169" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 50, 169</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">antiquitas dat dignitatem verbis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:24" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 3, 24</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:38 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 38 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n2895.4" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2895.5" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The occurrences of antiquity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the history of ancient times</hi>, <hi rend="ital">antiquity</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tenenda est omnis antiquitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:5:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 5, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">memoria antiquitatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:59:214" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 59, 214</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">antiquitatis iter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:60:256 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 60, 256 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">antiquitatis amator,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:18:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 18, 1</bibl></cit> Bremi and Dähne; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:ib. 20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 20</bibl> al.—In <number>plur.</number>, <hi rend="ital">a title of historical</hi> or <hi rend="ital">archœological works</hi>, <hi rend="ital">antiquities;</hi> cf. Plin. praef.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:5:13" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 5, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Varro in antiquitatibus rerum humanarum scripsit, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:11:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 11, 1</bibl></cit> et saep. —</sense><sense id="n2895.6" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Men of former times</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the ancients</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">errabat multis in rebus antiquitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:33" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 33</bibl></cit>; cf. Hand, Wopk. Lectt. Tull. p. 209; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:11:27" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 11, 27</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">antiquitas melius ea, quae erant vera, cernebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:12:26" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 12, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fabulose narravit antiquitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 19, 42, § 85</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:1 al" default="NO" valid="yes">19, 4, 19, § 1 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n2895.7" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The condition</hi><pb n="133" /> <cb n="ANTI" />  or <hi rend="ital">state of former times</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">Et soror tua Sodoma et filiae ejus revertentur ad antiquitatem suam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,053:16:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Ezech. 16, 55</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">ter.</hi>—</sense><sense id="n2895.8" n="II" level="1"> Esp., with the access. idea of moral excellence (cf. antiquus, II. C.), <hi rend="ital">the good old times</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the honesty of the good old times</hi>, <hi rend="ital">integrity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">uprightness</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">P. Rutilius documentum fuit virtutis, antiquitatis, prudentiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,030:chapter=10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rab. Post. 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">his gravissimae antiquitatis viris probatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:chapter=3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec plena sunt antiquitatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:18:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Planc. 18, 45</bibl></cit>; Sall. H. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. G. 2, 209</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">exemplar antiquitatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:5:15:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 5, 15, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
antiquitus: <entryFree id="n2896" type="main" key="anti_qui^tu^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antīquĭtŭs</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. antiquus <sense id="n2896.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
antiquo: <entryFree id="n2897" type="main" key="anti_quo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antīquo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>antiquus; cf.: veto, vetus</etym>. <sense id="n2897.0" n="I" level="1"> In class. Lat. only a t. t. of civil life, <hi rend="ital">to leave it in its ancient state</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to restore a thing to its former condition</hi> (antiquare est in modum pristinum reducere, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=26" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 26</bibl> Müll.).—Hence of a bill, <hi rend="ital">to reject it</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not to adopt it</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">legem agrariam antiquari facile passus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:21:73" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 21, 73</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 58</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:30:55" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 30, 55</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">Piso operam dat, ut ea rogatio antiquetur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 13</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 6</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 45, 35</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:39" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 39</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:40" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 40</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">legem antiquāstis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:3:17:38" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 3, 17, 38</bibl></cit> (cf. the letter A, abbrev.): <cit><quote lang="la">plebiscitum primus antiquo abrogoque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 30</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2897.1" n="II" level="1"> In eccl. Lat., <hi rend="ital">to make old</hi>: Dicendo novum, veteravit prius; quod autem antiquatur prope interitum est, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,019:8:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Heb. 8, 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antiquus: <entryFree id="n2898" type="main" key="anti_quus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antīquus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>a diff. orthog. for anticus, from ante</etym> (of that which is before in time, while <sense id="n2898.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">anticus</hi> denotes that which is before in space; cf. Vel. Long. p. 2223 P.), <hi rend="ital">that has been</hi> or <hi rend="ital">has been done before</hi>, <hi rend="ital">old</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ancient</hi>, <hi rend="ital">former</hi> (opp. <hi rend="ital">novus</hi>, that has not previously existed, new; while <hi rend="ital">vetus</hi>, that has existed a long time, is opp. <hi rend="ital">recens</hi>, that has not been long in existence, recent; cf. Manut. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:11:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 11, 21</bibl>; Lind. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:154" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 154</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:1:2:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 1, 2, 29</bibl>; Doed. Syn. IV. p. 82 sq.). </sense><sense id="n2898.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">Juppiter Alcumenam rediget in antiquam concordiam conjugis,</quote> <trans><tr>to her former harmony with her husband</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 2, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc timet, Ne tua duritia antiqua illa etiam adaucta sit,</quote> <trans><tr>thy former severity</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 1, 26</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:1:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hec. 1, 2, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:900" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 900</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">causam suscepisti antiquiorem memoriā tuā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,012:9:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rab. Perd. 9, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tres epistulas tuas accepi: igitur antiquissimae cuique respondeo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 9, 9</bibl></cit>: antiquior dies in tuis erat adscripta litteris, quam in Caesaris, <hi rend="ital">an earlier</hi> or <hi rend="ital">older date</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ad Q. Fr. 3, 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 58</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nilus antiquo sua flumina reddidit alveo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:423" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 423</bibl></cit> et saep.— Hence, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2898.2" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">antīqui</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the ancients</hi>, esp. <hi rend="ital">the ancient writers</hi> (i. e. those whose age has been long past; while <hi rend="ital">veteres</hi> denotes those who have lived and acted for a long time): <cit><quote lang="la">antiquorum auctoritas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:4:13" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Am. 4, 13</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:4:117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 4, 117</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 2, 89</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">quod decus antiqui summum bonum esse dixerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:21:55" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 1, 21, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">habemus Scaurum in antiquis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:30:116" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 30, 116</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 78</bibl> et saep.—And so in gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">in antiquis est sapientia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Job, 12, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sapientia omnium antiquorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,034:39:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Eccli. 39, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dictum est antiquis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:5:21 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 5, 21 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">facere in antiquum,</quote> <trans><tr>to restore a thing to its former condition</tr>, <tr>to place on its old footing</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:33:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 33, 40</bibl></cit> dub.—Antiquus and vetus are often conjoined: veterem atque antiquam rem (<hi rend="ital">old and antiquated</hi>) novam ad vos proferam, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:prol. 118" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. prol. 118</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:154" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 154</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:2:2:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 2, 2, 45</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:5:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 5, 2, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:1:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pers. 1, 2, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:2:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 2, 2, 106</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 3, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vetera tantum et antiqua mirari,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Or. 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">simultas vetus et antiqua,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:15:53" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 15, 53</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:21 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 21 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n2898.3" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">an-tīquum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">antiquity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the things of olden times</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nec quicquam antiqui Pico, nisi nomina, restat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:396" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 396</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">novissima et antiqua,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:138:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 138, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">antiqua ne intueamini,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:43:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Isa. 43, 18</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2898.4" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2898.5" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, = praeteritus, <hi rend="ital">past</hi>, <hi rend="ital">gone by</hi>, <hi rend="ital">former</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vulnus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:1:5:38" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 1, 5, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vigor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:12:32" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tr. 5, 12, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">carcer,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:6:721" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 6, 721</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:2:394" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 2, 394</bibl>.—So often in eccl. Lat.: <cit><quote lang="la">dies antiqui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:4:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Deut. 4, 32</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:15:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 15, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">anni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,047:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Mal. 3, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:15:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 15, 21</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2898.6" n="B" level="2"> In <hi rend="ital">comp.</hi> and <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">that is before</hi> or <hi rend="ital">first in rank</hi> or <hi rend="ital">importance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">more</hi> or <hi rend="ital">most celebrated</hi>, <hi rend="ital">famous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">preferable</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">better</hi> (antiquior: <cit><quote lang="la">melior,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 425, 32</bibl></cit>): genere antiquior, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 426, 3</bibl>: quanto antiquius quam etc., Lucil. ib.; Varr. ib.: quod <cb n="ANTI" /> honestius, id mihi est antiquius, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">antiquior ei fuit laus et gloria quam regnum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:37" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 37</bibl></cit>: antiquiorem mortem turpitudine habere, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 3, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque habui quicquam antiquius quam ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:11:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 11, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne quid existimem antiquius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:13:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 13, 3</bibl></cit>: neque prius neque antiquius quicquam habuit, quam ut, etc., Vel. 2, 52; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:11" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">judiciorum causam antiquissimam se habiturum dixit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navalis apparatus ei antiquissima cura fuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:10:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 10, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">12, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 32</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:31 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 9, 31 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n2898.7" n="C" level="2"> With the access. idea of simplicity, purity, innocence, <hi rend="ital">of the old fashion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">good</hi>, <hi rend="ital">simple</hi>, <hi rend="ital">honest</hi>, etc. (cf. antiquitas, II. A., and our phrase <hi rend="ital">the good old times</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">antiquis est adulescens moribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:1:1:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 1, 1, 37</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:2:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 2, 2, 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo antiquā virtute et fide,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:3:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 3, 88</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homines antiqui, qui ex suā naturā ceteros fingerent,</quote> <trans><tr>people of the old stamp</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:9:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 9, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vestigia antiqui officii,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vide quam sim antiquorum hominum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 9, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vir sanctus, antiquus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 2, 9</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2898.8" n="D" level="2"> With the access. idea of veneration, honor, <hi rend="ital">old</hi>, <hi rend="ital">venerable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">illustrious</hi>: antiquum veteres etiam pro nobili posuere, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=22" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 22</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">terra antiqua potens armis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:531" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 531</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 164</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbs,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 11, 540</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Longior antiquis visa Maeotis hiems,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:3:12:2" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 3, 12, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Sabinae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Med. 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Amyclae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:314" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 8, 314</bibl></cit>. —So, in eccl. Lat., after the Heb., of God: <cit><quote lang="la">Antiquus Dierum,</quote> <trans><tr>the Ancient of Days</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,056:7:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Dan. 7, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">7, 13</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 22</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2898.9" n="E" level="2"> Sometimes = vetus, <hi rend="ital">that has been in existence a long time</hi>, <hi rend="ital">old</hi>: Athenae, antiquum opulentum oppidum, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 470, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit> p. 506, 1: amnis, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 192, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hospes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:1:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 1, 2, 17</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 82</bibl>: veterem Anchisen agnoscit amicum); so, <cit><quote lang="la">amicus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,034:9:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Eccli. 9, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">discipulus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:21:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 21, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">artificium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">genus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,014:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dat. 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">templa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:2:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 2, 104</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">antiquissima scripta,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 28</bibl></cit>: saxum antiquum (i. e. <hi rend="ital">which for a long time had lain in this place</hi>), ingens, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:897" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 897</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne transfer terminos antiquos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,029:22:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Prov. 22, 28</bibl></cit> et saep.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">antīquum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">an old custom</hi> or <hi rend="ital">habit.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2898.10" n="a" level="4"> In mal. part.: <cit><quote lang="la">antiquum hoc obtines tuum, tardus ut sis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:2:102" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 3, 2, 102</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n2898.11" n="b" level="4"> In bon. part.: <cit><quote lang="la">O optume hospes, pol Crito antiquum obtines!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:5:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 5, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ac tu ecastor morem antiquum atque ingenium obtines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:4:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hec. 5, 4, 20</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2898.12" n="F" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Aged</hi>: antiqua erilis fida custos corporis, Enn. Medea, ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 39, 2</bibl> (as a transl. of the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">*i*ialaio\n oi)/kwn kth=ma despoi/nhs e)mh=s</foreign>): Cives antiqui, amici majorum meūm, Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:46:155" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 46, 155</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Butes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:647" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 647</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">antiqui Neleïa Nestoris arva,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:1:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 1, 63</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:50:3:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 50, 3, 1</bibl>.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">antīquē</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">an-tīquĭtŭs</orth> (formed from antiquus, as humanitus, divinitus, from humanus, divinus; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 1015</bibl>). </sense><sense id="n2898.13" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">In former times</hi>, <hi rend="ital">of old</hi>, <hi rend="ital">anciently</hi> (only in prose; most freq. in the histt.; never in Cic.). Form <orth extent="full" lang="la">antīquĭ-tŭs</orth>: <cit><quote lang="la">Belgas Rhenum antiquitus transductos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">7, 32</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tectum antiquitus constitutum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:13:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 13, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:42" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 42</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:60" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Aug. 60</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">94</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,006:11:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Jos. 11, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:27:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 1 Reg. 27, 8</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Titanas in eā antiquissime regnāsse,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 11</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2898.14" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">From ancient times;</hi> form <orth extent="full" lang="la">antīquĭtŭs</orth>; sometimes with <hi rend="ital">inde</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ab ... ad</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:31" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 31</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum Pythagoras acceptam sine dubio antiquitus opinionem vulgaverit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:10:12" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 10, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam inde antiquitus insita pertinacia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hi sunt jam inde antiquitus castellani, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 34, 27</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:82:7" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 82, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum (hoc studium) antiquitus usque a Chirone ad nostra tempora apud omnes duraverit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:10:30" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 10, 30</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2898.15" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">In the old way</hi>, <hi rend="ital">style</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">fashion;</hi> form <orth extent="full" lang="la">antīquē</orth>: <cit><quote lang="la">nimis antique dicere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 66</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">simplicius et antiquius permutatione mercium uti,</quote> <trans><tr>in the simpler and more ancient manner</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 5</bibl></cit>.—Esp., <hi rend="ital">in the good old style</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the way</hi> or <hi rend="ital">fashion of former times</hi>: quanto antiquius, quam facere hoc, fecisse videatis, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 426, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antirrhinon: <entryFree id="n2899" type="greek" key="antirrhi_non"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antirrhīnon</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">-um</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nti/rrinon</foreign>; also <orth extent="full" lang="la">ănarrhīnon</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)na)rrinon</foreign>, <sense id="n2899.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wild lion's-mouth</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Antirrhinum Orontium, Linn.: antirrhinum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:129" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 10, 80, § 129</bibl></cit> Jan; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 86</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antisagoge: <entryFree id="n2900" type="greek" key="anti_sa^go_ge_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antīsăgōgē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nteisagwgh/</foreign>, <sense id="n2900.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a figure of speech by which one thing adduced</hi> <cb n="ANTI" /> <hi rend="ital">is opposed to another</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a counter-assertion</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 5, p. 172</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antiscii: <entryFree id="n2901" type="greek" key="antisci^i"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antiscĭi</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nti/skio</foreign>. (counter-shadows), <sense id="n2901.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">people on the other side of the equator</hi>, <hi rend="ital">whose shadows are cast in the opposite direction from ours</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 22, 15 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
antisigma: <entryFree id="n2902" type="greek" key="anti^sigma^"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antĭsigmă</orth>, <itype>ătis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nti/sigma</foreign>. <sense id="n2902.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A character</hi>, Ↄ, <hi rend="ital">which the emperor Claudius wished to introduce into Latin for</hi> ps = the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">y</foreign>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 558</bibl> P.; cf. Schne<bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Gram. 1, 5</bibl>; Wordsworth's Early Lat. p. 9.— </sense><sense id="n2902.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A critical mark</hi>, Ↄ, <hi rend="ital">placed before a verse which is to be transposed</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 1, 20</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antisophista: <entryFree id="n2903" type="greek" key="anti^so^phista"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antĭsŏphista</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ntisofisth/s</foreign>, <sense id="n2903.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a counter-sophist</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">a grammarian who takes the opposite side of a question</hi> (only post-Aug.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:3:127" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 3, 127</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:11" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 11</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,004:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Gram. 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antispastus: <entryFree id="n2904" type="greek" key="antispastus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antispastus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nti/spastos</foreign> (reversed), in metre (sc. pes), <sense id="n2904.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an antispast</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a foot in verse</hi>, ˘¯¯˘, i. e. the choriambus reversed, e. g. Mĕdūllīnă, <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 478</bibl> P.; <cit><quote lang="la">hence: antispasticum metrum,</quote> <trans><tr>verse consisting of antispasts</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> p. 505</bibl></cit> P.</sense></entryFree>
antispodos: <entryFree id="n2905" type="greek" key="antispo^dos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antispŏdos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nti/spodos</foreign>, <sense id="n2905.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">ashes used instead of spodium</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:133" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 13, 35, § 133</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antissa: <entryFree id="n2906" type="main" key="Antissa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antissa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/antissa</foreign>, <sense id="n2906.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in the southern part of the island of Lesbos</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Kalas Limneonas</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:287" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 287</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 31, 39, § 89</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">An-tissaei</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">inhabitants of Antissa</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 31</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antistatus: <entryFree id="n2907" type="hapax" key="antista_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antistātus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>v. antesto</etym>, <sense id="n2907.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">superiority in rank</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">angelorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Val. 13</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
antistes: <entryFree id="n2908" type="main" key="antiste^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antistĕs</orth>, <itype>ĭtis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> and <gen>f.</gen> (<sense id="n2908.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fem.</hi> also <orth extent="full" lang="la">antistĭta</orth>, <itype>ae, like hospita from hospes, sospita from sospes, clienta from cliens</itype>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 2200</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 77</bibl> P.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 650</bibl> P.) [antisto = antesto, q. v.; pr. <pos>adj.</pos>, standing before], <hi rend="ital">an overseer</hi>, <hi rend="ital">president.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2908.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2908.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen. (rare): <cit><quote lang="la">vindemiatorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:21:6" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 3, 21, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">imperii Romani,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Apol. 1</bibl></cit>. —In <hi rend="ital">fem.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a female overseer</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">latrinarum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Pall. 4 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—Far more freq., </sense><sense id="n2908.3" n="B" level="2"> Esp., <hi rend="ital">an overseer of a temple</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a high-priest</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">caerimoniarum et sacrorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:39:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Dom. 39, 104</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:54" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 54 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Jovis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,006:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Lys. 3, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 34</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes">1, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sacrorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:2:113" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 2, 113</bibl></cit>.— In the O. T. simply <hi rend="ital">a priest</hi>: et sanctificarentur antistites, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,016:29:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Par. 29, 34</bibl>.—In the Christian writers, <hi rend="ital">a bishop</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 18</bibl> et saep.—</sense><sense id="n2908.4" n="C" level="2"> In <hi rend="ital">fem.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a female overseer of a temple</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a chief priestess.</hi>— Form <orth extent="full" lang="la">antistĕs</orth>: <cit><quote lang="la">adsiduae templi antistites,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 20</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 23, 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:14" default="NO" valid="yes">31, 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">perita antistes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:1:1" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 1, 1</bibl></cit>, n. 1: <cit><quote lang="la">templi aeditua et antistes pudicitia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Cult. Fem. 1</bibl></cit>.— Form <orth extent="full" lang="la">antistĭta</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 3, 2, 10</bibl>: Veneris antistita, Pollio ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 77</bibl> P.; Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 487, 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">fani antistitae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 45</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:13:20:22" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 13, 20, 22</bibl>: antistita Phoebi, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Cassandra</hi>, so called as prophetess, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:410" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 410</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cybeles antistita,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Verg.</author> Cir. 166</bibl></cit>; Corn. Sev. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 77</bibl> P.—</sense><sense id="n2908.5" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a master in any science</hi> or <hi rend="ital">art</hi>, as in Engl. <hi rend="ital">high-priest</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">artis dicendi antistes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:46:202" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 46, 202</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cultor et antistes doctorum virorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:3:14:1" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 3, 14, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">artium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:1:10" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 11, 1, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sapientiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:110" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 30, 31, § 110</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">philosophiae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 5, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">juris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:1:69" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 1, 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">justitiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:14:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 14, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">studiorum liberalium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:10:46:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 10, 46, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
antisthenes: <entryFree id="n2909" type="main" key="Antisthe^nes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antisthĕnes</orth>, <itype>is and ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)antisqe/nhs</foreign>, <sense id="n2909.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a pupil of Socrates</hi>, <hi rend="ital">teacher of Diogenes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and founder of the Cynic philosophy</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Antisthenes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:13:32" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 13, 32</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:17:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 17, 62</bibl>.—In <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">Antisthenae multi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:14:1:29" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 14, 1, 29</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
antistita: <entryFree id="n2910" type="main" key="antisti^ta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antistĭta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, v. antistes.</entryFree>
antistitium: <entryFree id="n2911" type="hapax" key="antisti^ti^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antistĭtĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>antistes</etym>, <sense id="n2911.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the office of an</hi> antistes, <hi rend="ital">the chief-priest's office</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 2, p. 34</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antisto: <entryFree id="n2912" type="main" key="antisto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antisto</orth>, v. antesto.</entryFree>
antistrophe: <entryFree id="n2913" type="hapax" key="antistro/phe_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antistro/phē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ntistrofh/</foreign>. <sense id="n2913.0" n="I" level="1"> In the chorus of the Greek and Roman tragedy, <hi rend="ital">the antistrophe answering to the strophe</hi>, Victorin. p. 2051 P.—</sense><sense id="n2913.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A rhetorical figure</hi>, <hi rend="ital">when several parts of a period end with the same word</hi> = conversio, q. v.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 5, p. 175</bibl>; Jul. <bibl default="NO"><author>Rufin.</author> 35, p. 211</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antithesis: <entryFree id="n2914" type="greek" key="anti^the^sis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antĭthĕsis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nti/qesis</foreign>, a gram. ng., <sense id="n2914.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the putting of one letter for another</hi> (e. g. olli for illi, impete for impetu), <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 249</bibl> P.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 437</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
antitheton: <entryFree id="n2915" type="greek" key="anti^the^ton"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antĭthĕton</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nti/qeton</foreign>, <sense id="n2915.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">opposition</hi>,<pb n="134" /> <cb n="ANTO" />  <hi rend="ital">antithesis</hi>, a rhetor. fig., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:50:166" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 50, 166</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:1:85" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 1, 85</bibl> (e. g. frigida pugnabant calidis, humentia siccis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 19</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:3:81" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 3, 81</bibl>).</sense></entryFree>
antitheus: <entryFree id="n2916" type="greek" key="anti^the^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antĭthĕus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nti/qeos</foreign> (a counter-deity), <sense id="n2916.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who pretends to be God</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 4, p. 134</bibl>.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">the devil</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 2, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antium: <entryFree id="n2917" type="main" key="Anti^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/antion</foreign>. <sense id="n2917.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An ancient town in Latium distinguished for the temple of Fortune</hi> (<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:35:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 35, 1</bibl>), <hi rend="ital">not far from the sea-coast</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Porto d'Anzio</hi>, the birthplace of Nero, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 9, § 27</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 1738</bibl>; cf. Mann. Ital. 1, 618; Müll. Roms Campagn. 2, 271 sq.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n2917.1" n="II" level="1"> Derivv. </sense><sense id="n2917.2" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Antian</hi>: Hercules Antianus, <hi rend="ital">honored at Antium</hi>, Cic. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 284, 1</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n2917.3" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Antium</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Antian</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 14</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:12 al" default="NO" valid="yes">8, 12 al.</bibl>—So, Valerius Antias, <hi rend="ital">a historian before Livy</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:7:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 7, 10</bibl>; cf. Bähr, <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> Gesch. 260; Teuffel, Rom. <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> § 142, 3.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭātes</orth>, <itype>um</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Antium</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">naves Antiatum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 14 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n2917.4" n="C" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭātīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Antian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fortunae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:57" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 57</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2917.5" n="D" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, the same: <cit><quote lang="la">templum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:1:8" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 1, 8</bibl></cit>, n. 2.</sense></entryFree>
antius: <entryFree id="n2918" type="main" key="Anti^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n2918.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">name of a Roman</hi> gens; <cit><quote lang="la">hence, Antia lex (by Antius Restio), against prodigality,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:24" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 24</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 2, 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antizeugmenon: <entryFree id="n2919" type="greek" key="antizeugme^non"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antizeugmĕnon</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ntizeu/gmenon</foreign>, <sense id="n2919.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a grammatical figure</hi>, <hi rend="ital">by which several clauses are referred to one verb</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 5, p. 176</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antlia: <entryFree id="n2920" type="greek" key="antli^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antlĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nti/a</foreign>, <sense id="n2920.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a machine for drawing water</hi>, <hi rend="ital">worked with the foot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a pump</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:9:14:3" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 9, 14, 3</bibl>; * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:51" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 51</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antlo: <entryFree id="n2921" type="main" key="antlo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antlo</orth>, v. anclo.</entryFree>
antodice: <entryFree id="n2922" type="main" key="Anto^di^ce_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antŏdĭcē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n2922.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one of the Danaids</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 170" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 170</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antonia: <entryFree id="n2923" type="main" key="Anto_ni^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antōnĭa</orth>, v. Antonius.</entryFree>
antonianus: <entryFree id="n2924" type="main" key="Anto_ni^a_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antōnĭānus</orth>, v. Antonius.</entryFree>
antoniaster: <entryFree id="n2925" type="hapax" key="Anto_ni^aster"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antōnĭaster</orth>, <itype>tri</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>from Antonius, as surdaster from surdus, parasitaster from parasitus; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 628</bibl> P.</etym>, <sense id="n2925.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a servile imitator of the orator Antonius</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a petty Antony</hi>: hic noster Antoniaster, Cic. Varen. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 617</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
antoninus: <entryFree id="n2926" type="main" key="Anto_ni_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antōnīnus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>Antonius</etym>, <sense id="n2926.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Antonine</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the name of several Roman emperors;</hi> among whom the most distinguished were Antoninus Pius and M. Aurelius Antoninus Philosophus, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 834 sq.</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">856</bibl> sq. —Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Antōnīnĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Antonine</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Eutr.</author> 8, 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Lampr.</author> Elag. 24 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
antoniopolitae: <entryFree id="n2927" type="main" key="Anto_ni^o^po^li_tae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antōnĭŏpŏlītae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2927.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Antoniopolis in Lydia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 25, 30, § 111</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antonius: <entryFree id="n2928" type="main" key="Anto_ni^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antōnĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2928.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">name of a Roman</hi> gens. </sense><sense id="n2928.1" n="I" level="1"> M. Antonius, <hi rend="ital">Marc Antony</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a distinguished triumvir</hi>, <hi rend="ital">conquered by Octavianus at Actium</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a mortal enemy of Cicero.</hi> —</sense><sense id="n2928.2" n="II" level="1"> M. Antonius, <hi rend="ital">a celebrated orator just before the age of Cicero;</hi> cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:37 sq" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 37 sq.</bibl>; Ellendt, Cic. Brut. p. lxii. sq.; Bähr, <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> Gesch. 355; Teuffel, Rom. <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> § 139.—</sense><sense id="n2928.3" n="III" level="1"> C.
