Antonius, <hi rend="ital">Cicero's colleague in the consulship.</hi>—</sense><sense id="n2928.4" n="IV" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Fem.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Antōnĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <hi rend="ital">a daughter of the triumvir Antonius</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 10, 36, § 16</bibl>.—Derivv. </sense><sense id="n2928.5" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Antōnĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Antonius</hi>: leges Antonias fregi, i. e. <hi rend="ital">proposed by the triumvir Antonius</hi>, Lentul. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:12:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 12, 14 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl> B. and K.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Antōnĭi</orth>, <hi rend="ital">the adherents of the triumvir Antonius</hi>, Lepid. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 34</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2928.6" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Antō-nĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> </sense><sense id="n2928.7" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the triumvir Antonius</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">contra Antonianos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 34</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">12, 25</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:74" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 74</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 2:25" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 2, 25</bibl>; hence, also <orth extent="full" lang="la">Antōnĭā-nae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (sc. orationes), <hi rend="ital">the orations of Cicero against Antonius</hi> (com. called <hi rend="ital">Philippicae;</hi> v. Philippicus), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:11" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 7, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:13:1" default="NO">13, 1</bibl> and 21.—</sense><sense id="n2928.8" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the orator Antonius</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dicendi ratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 13</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
antonomasia: <entryFree id="n2929" type="greek" key="anto^no^ma^si^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antŏnŏmăsĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ntonomasi/a</foreign>, <sense id="n2929.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a rhetorical figure</hi>, <hi rend="ital">by which</hi>, <hi rend="ital">instead of the name</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an epithet of a person is employed</hi> (e. g. instead of Scipio, Eversor Carthaginis; instead of Achilles, Pelides; <cit><quote lang="la">instead of Juno, Saturnia, etc.),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:6:29" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 6, 29</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:6:43" default="NO">8, 6, 43</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antonomasivus: <entryFree id="n2930" type="main" key="anto^no^ma^si_vus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antŏnŏmăsīvus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>antonomasia</etym>,<cb n="ANUS" />  <sense id="n2930.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">forming an antonomasia</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 2, 171</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 615</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antroare: <entryFree id="n2931" type="gloss" key="antroare"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antroare</orth>: gratias referre, <sense id="n2931.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to requite</hi>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=9" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 9</bibl> Müll.; cf. Kuhn in Zeitschr. für Vergl. Sprachf. 7, p. 64 sq.; Vanicek, Etym. p. 291.</sense></entryFree>
antron: <entryFree id="n2932" type="main" key="Antro_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Antrōn</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)antrw/n</foreign> (Hom. Il. 2, 697), <sense id="n2932.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Thessaly</hi> (Phthiotis), now <hi rend="ital">Fano</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 42</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:67" default="NO" valid="yes">42, 67</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
antrum: <entryFree id="n2933" type="greek" key="antrum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">antrum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/ntron</foreign>, <sense id="n2933.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a cave</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cavern</hi>, <hi rend="ital">grotto</hi> (almost entirely confined to the poets). </sense><sense id="n2933.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">succedere antro,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:5:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 5, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">subire antra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 121</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">occulere se antro,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:8:315" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 8, 315</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ingens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gratum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 5, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gelida antra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:509" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 509</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">silvestria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Dionaeo sub antro,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:1:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 1, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vos Caesarem Pierio recreatis antro,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 4, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quibus antris audiar?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 25, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">harenosum Libyae Jovis antrum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5:1:103" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 5, 1, 103</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">effossa antra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:13:60" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 13, 60</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:4:6" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 4, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:6:149" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 6, 149</bibl> et saep.—In prose mostly in eccl. Lat., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:23:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 23, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,026:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Jud. 6, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:13:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 1 Reg. 13, 6</bibl>; ib. Job, 37, 8; <cit><quote lang="la">38, 40: per antra et cavas rupes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:43" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 43</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2933.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig., of <hi rend="ital">the hollow of a tree</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ekesae arboris antrum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 44</bibl></cit>.—Of <hi rend="ital">a sedan</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">clausum antrum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:4:21" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 4, 21</bibl></cit>.—Later, of <hi rend="ital">any cavity</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">narium,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">palati,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pectoris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Psych. 6, 774</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anubis: <entryFree id="n2934" type="main" key="A^nu_bis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănūbis</orth>, <itype>is and ĭdis</itype> (<case>acc.</case> Anubin, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:10:41" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 10, 41</bibl>: <sense id="n2934.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">Anubim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:131" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 9, 46, § 131</bibl></cit> Jan), <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/anoubis</foreign> [Egyptian], <hi rend="ital">an Egyptian deity which was represented with the head of a dog</hi> (cf. Müll. Archaeol. § 408), <hi rend="ital">tutelary deity of the chase</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">latrator Anubis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:698" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 698</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:2:13:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 2, 13, 11</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anularis: <entryFree id="n2935" type="main" key="a_nu^la_ris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ānŭlāris</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>anulus</etym>, <sense id="n2935.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">relating to a signet-ring;</hi> hence, anulare (sc. genus coloris), <hi rend="ital">a white color prepared from chalk</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mixed with glass beads</hi>, <hi rend="ital">such as were worn in rings</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 6, 30, § 48</bibl>. Cf. anularius.</sense></entryFree>
anularius: <entryFree id="n2936" type="main" key="a_nu^la_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ānŭlārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2936.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to a signet-ring</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">creta = anulare (v. anularis),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 7, 14</bibl></cit>: * Scalae anulariae, <hi rend="ital">a place in Rome</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in the eighth district</hi> (the origin of the name is unknown), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:72" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 72</bibl>.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ānŭlārĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a ring-maker</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 26, 86</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anulatus: <entryFree id="n2937" type="main" key="a_nu^la_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ānŭlātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2937.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">furnished</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ornamented with a ring</hi>: aures, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:5:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 5, 2, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">anulati pedes,</quote> <trans><tr>fettered</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 9, p. 222, 30</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9</bibl>, p. 234, 15.</sense></entryFree>
anulus: <entryFree id="n2938" type="main" key="a_nu^lus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ānŭlus</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">ann-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>2. anus, like circulus from circum, not a <lbl>dim.</lbl></etym>, <sense id="n2938.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a ring</hi>, esp. <hi rend="ital">for the finger</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a finger-ring;</hi> and for sealing, <hi rend="ital">a seal-ring</hi>, <hi rend="ital">signet-ring.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2938.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">ille suum anulum opposuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:2:3:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 2, 3, 76</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de digito anulum Detraho,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:1:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 1, 37</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:2:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 3, 2, 49</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:3:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hec. 5, 3, 31</bibl> et saep.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:312" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 312</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1008" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 1008</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1014" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 1014</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">(Gyges) anulum detraxit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:9:38" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 9, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gemmatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:46" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 46</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:33" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Caes. 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:73" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tib. 73</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">anulo tabulas obsignare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:2:3:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 2, 3, 67</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sigilla anulo imprimere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 26, 85</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ad Q. Fr. 1, 1, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 1, 5</bibl> sqq. et saep.—The right to wear a gold ring was possessed, in the time of the Republic, only by the knights (equites); hence, equestris, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:7:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 7, 53</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">anulum invenit = eques factus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 76</bibl></cit>.—So also jus anulorum = dignitas equestris, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:33" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 33</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">donatus anulo aureo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 39</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Galb. 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vit.:12 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Vit. 12 al.</bibl>; cf. Mayor ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:7:89" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 7, 89</bibl>; Smith. Dict. Antiq.—</sense><sense id="n2938.2" n="II" level="1"> Of other articles in the form of rings. </sense><sense id="n2938.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A ring for curtains</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">velares anuli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 13, 9, 18, § 62</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n2938.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A link of a chain</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:150" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 15, 43, § 150</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:2:29" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 2, 29</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Irons for the feet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fetters</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">anulus cruribus aptus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:169" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 14, 169</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2938.5" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A curled lock of hair</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a ringlet</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">comarum anulus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:2:66" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 2, 66</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2938.6" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A round ornament upon the capitals of Doric columns</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">anuli columnarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 4, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2938.7" n="E" level="2"> Anuli virgei, <hi rend="ital">rings made of willow rods</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:124" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 29, 37, § 124</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2939" type="hapax" key="a_nu^lus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ānŭlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>1. anus</etym>, <sense id="n2939.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the posteriors</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fundament</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 159</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anus: <entryFree id="n2940" type="main" key="a_nus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ānus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>for as-nus; cf. Sanscr. ās, = to sit, seat one's self; <foreign lang="greek">h(=mai</foreign> (Dor. <foreign lang="greek">h(=smai</foreign>) <foreign lang="greek">ka/q-hmai</foreign>, Varr.; others refer it to 2. anus, from its form</etym>, <sense id="n2940.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the posteriors</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fundament.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2940.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:7:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 7, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1011,001:Comp. 227" default="NO"><author>Scrib.</author> Comp. 227</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2940.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg>, disease of the anus, <hi rend="ital">piles</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hemorrhoids</hi> (eccl. <cb n="ANXI" /> Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">quinque anos aureos facietis, i. e. representations of,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:6:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Reg. 6, 5</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">bis;</hi> 6, 11; 6, 17.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2941" type="hapax" key="a_nus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ānus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>related to 2. an- = <foreign lang="greek">a)mfi/</foreign>; prim. signif. a rounding, a circular form; hence also 1. anulus; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:8, p. 76" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, 8, p. 76</bibl> Müll.</etym>, <sense id="n2941.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an iron ring for the feet</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:1:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 1, 1, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2942" type="main" key="a^nus3" n="3"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype> (also uis, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 474, 30</bibl>, or Trag. v. 232 Vahl.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 46</bibl>; Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 494, 24</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:4:16" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 4, 16</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 718</bibl> P.; v. domus, fructus, victus), <gen>f.</gen> <etym>cf. old Germ. Ano, Ana, = great-grandfather, great-grandmother; Germ. Ahn, ancestor</etym>, <sense id="n2942.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an old woman</hi> (<hi rend="ital">married</hi> or <hi rend="ital">unmarried</hi>), <hi rend="ital">a matron</hi>, <hi rend="ital">old wife</hi>, <hi rend="ital">old maid</hi> (sometimes in an honorable sense, but com. as a term of contempt). </sense><sense id="n2942.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: tremulis anus attulit artubus lumen, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:20:40" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 20, 40</bibl> (Ann. v. 36 Vahl.); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:3:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 2, 3, 75</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid nuntias super anu?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:4:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cist. 4, 1, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ejus anuis causā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">prudens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:17:47" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 17, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:631" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 631</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">huic anui non satis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 1, 2, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:18:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 18, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,015:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 1 Tim. 5, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae est anus tam delira, quae ista timeat?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:21:48" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 21, 48</bibl></cit> et saep.—Sometimes for <hi rend="ital">a female soothsayer</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sibyl</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:9:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 9, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:158" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 158</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2942.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> as <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">old</hi>, <hi rend="ital">aged</hi> (cf. senex, <hi rend="ital">old; old man</hi>, sometimes <hi rend="ital">old woman</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">anus matronae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:11" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">libertinam quamvis anum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=otho:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Oth. 2</bibl></cit>.—Also of animals, or inanimate things of the feminine gender: <cit><quote lang="la">cerva anus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:766" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 1, 766</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">charta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:68:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 68, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">testa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:1:106" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 1, 106</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">terra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 3, 5, § 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fici,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:82 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 15, 19, 21, § 82 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
anxie: <entryFree id="n2943" type="main" key="anxi^e_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anxĭē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. anxius <sense id="n2943.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
anxietas: <entryFree id="n2944" type="main" key="anxi^e^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anxĭĕtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>anxius</etym>. <sense id="n2944.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The quality</hi> or <hi rend="ital">state of</hi> anxius, <hi rend="ital">anxiety</hi> (as a per manent condition, while <hi rend="ital">angor</hi>, anguish, is only momentary; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Hab. Syn. 108, and v. angor),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:12:27" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 12, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">perpetua anxie tas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:13:211" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 13, 211</bibl></cit>.—But sometimes = angor, <hi rend="ital">temporary anguish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fear</hi>, <hi rend="ital">trouble</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:1:4:8" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 1, 4, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:13" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">divortii anxietate mortuus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:186" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 53, 54, § 186</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2944.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Anxious care</hi>, <hi rend="ital">carefulness</hi> in regard to a thing (only post-Aug.): quaerendi, judicandi, comparandi anxietas, Quint. prooem. 8 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">anxietas et quasi morositas disputationis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:3:12" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 3, 12</bibl></cit>; cf. anxius, B.</sense></entryFree>
anxietudo: <entryFree id="n2945" type="main" key="anxi^e^tu_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anxĭĕtūdo</orth>, v. anxitudo.</entryFree>
anxifer: <entryFree id="n2946" type="main" key="anxi^fer"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anxĭfer</orth>, <itype>fĕra, fĕrum</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>anxius-fero</etym>, <sense id="n2946.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">causing</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bringing anxiety</hi> (only in Cic.): <cit><quote lang="la">curae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:13:22" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 13, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dolorum vertices,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:9:21" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 2, 9, 21</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anxio: <entryFree id="n2947" type="main" key="anxi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anxĭo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>anxius</etym>, <sense id="n2947.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make uneasy</hi> or <hi rend="ital">anxious</hi> (only in late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">anxiatum iri,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 4, p. 155, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dum anxiaretur cor meum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:60:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 60, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anxiatus est super me spiritus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 142, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anxiosus: <entryFree id="n2948" type="hapax" key="anxi^o_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anxĭōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2948.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">full of anxiety; act.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">causing anxiety</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">uneasiness</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 3:2" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 3, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anxitudo: <entryFree id="n2949" type="main" key="anxi^tu_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anxĭtūdo</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (mostly ante-class.), and <orth extent="full" lang="la">anxĭĕtūdo</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (post-class. for the class. anxietas) [id.], <sense id="n2949.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">anxiety</hi>, <hi rend="ital">trouble</hi>, <hi rend="ital">anguish</hi>: animi, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 72, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:ib. 28" default="NO"><author>Att.</author> ib. 28</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:29" default="NO">29</bibl>.—Once also in Cic.: <cit><quote lang="la">anxitudo prona ad luctum, Rep. 2, 41: macerabatur anxietudine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Conf, 9:3" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Conf, 9, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anxietudinis poena,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul. Nol.</author> Ep. 14</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anxius: <entryFree id="n2950" type="main" key="anxi^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anxĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>v. ango</etym>, <sense id="n2950.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">distressed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">solicitous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">uneasy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">troubled</hi>, <hi rend="ital">anxious</hi> (as a permanent state of mind). </sense><sense id="n2950.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque omnes anxii, qui anguntur aliquando, nec qui anxii semper anguntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:12:27" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 12, 27</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">anxietas and angor.—But frequently momentary' anxiae aegritudines et acerbae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:15:34" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 15, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anxio animo aut sollicito esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:17:55" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 17, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">spiritus anxius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,050:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Bar. 3, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">senes morosi et anxii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:18:65" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 18, 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Oratio pauperis, cum anxius fuerit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:101:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 101, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anxius curis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:275" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 275</bibl></cit>: mentes, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:21:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 21, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">anxius angor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:993" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 993</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1158" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 1158</bibl>: anxium habere aliquem, <hi rend="ital">to bring one into trouble</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to make anxious</hi> or <hi rend="ital">solicitous</hi>, Auct. B. Afr. 71; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 65</bibl>.—With <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> animi or mentis: <cit><quote lang="la">animi anxius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 55:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 55, 4</bibl></cit> Cort., where Dietsch reads <hi rend="ital">animo</hi>, and Gerl. omits it altogether: <cit><quote lang="la">anxius mentis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0800,001:1:398" default="NO"><author>Albin.</author> 1, 398</bibl></cit> (for this <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> v. animus, II. B. 1.).—The object on account of which one is anxious or solicitous is put, </sense><sense id="n2950.2" n="(a)" level="5"> In <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">gloriā ejus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omine adverso,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vit.:8" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vit. 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">venturis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:7:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 7, 20</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2950.3" n="(b)" level="5"> In <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> (diff. from <pb n="135" /> <cb n="APAG" /> the preced. <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> animi and mentis): <cit><quote lang="la">inopiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">furti (i. e. ne furtum fiat),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:623" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 623</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vitae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:20:198" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 20, 198</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">securitatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 18, 20, § 74</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">potentiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 3, 38</bibl></cit>; in <case>acc.</case> vicem, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 35</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2950.4" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">de</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">de famā ingenii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:1:50" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 1, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de successore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:19" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de instantibus curis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:3:2" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 3, 2</bibl></cit>; with <hi rend="ital">pro</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:4:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 4, 21</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2950.5" n="(d)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad eventum alicujus rei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:8:592" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 8, 592</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">in</hi> and <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">noli anxius esse in divitiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,034:5:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Eccli. 5, 10</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">z</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">ne</hi> and <hi rend="ital">an</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">anxius, ne bellum oriatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 6:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 6, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anxius, an obsequium senatūs an studia plebis reperiret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 13</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2950.6" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2950.7" n="A" level="2"> In an <hi rend="ital">act.</hi> sense, <hi rend="ital">that makes anxious</hi>, <hi rend="ital">troubles</hi>, <hi rend="ital">awakens solicitude</hi>, <hi rend="ital">troublesome</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">curae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 56</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">anxius curis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:275" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 275</bibl></cit>): <cit><quote lang="la">timor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 89</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accessu propter aculeos anxio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 8, 18, § 33</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2950.8" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Prepared with anxious care</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">elegantia orationis neque morosa neque anxia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:15:7:3" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 15, 7, 3</bibl></cit>; cf. anxietas, II.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">anxĭē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">anxiously</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with anxiety</hi> (not in Cic.): <cit><quote lang="la">aliquid ferre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 82:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 82, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">auguria quaerere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:273" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 52, 114, § 273</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">certare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:23" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquam prosequi, Justin. 1, 4: loqui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:20:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 20, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anxie doctus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 5, 18</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">7, 7</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: anxius, Gargil. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:page=395" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> p. 395</bibl> Mai; <cit><quote lang="la">and formed by magis: magis anxie,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ad Caes. Ord. Re Publ. 2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> ad Caes. Ord. Re Publ. 2 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
anxur: <entryFree id="n2951" type="main" key="Anxur"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Anxur</orth> (rarely written <orth extent="full" lang="la">Anxyr</orth>, Prob. p. 1459 P.), <itype>ŭris</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (<gen>m.</gen>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:5:1" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 5, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:10:58 al" default="NO">10, 58 al.</bibl>, as lying upon a mountain of the same name). <sense id="n2951.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An ancient town in Latium</hi>, <hi rend="ital">situated not far from the sea-shore</hi>, afterwards also called Tarracina, now <hi rend="ital">Terracina</hi>, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=19" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Tarracina oppidum linguā Volscorum Anxur dictum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 9, § 59</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:5:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 5, 26</bibl>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Mann. Ital. 1, 626 sq. (this town had its name from a fountain in the neighborhood,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 7, 799</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:27:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 27, 38</bibl>.)—Hence, </sense><sense id="n2951.1" n="II" level="1"> Derivv. </sense><sense id="n2951.2" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Anxŭrus</orth>: <cit><quote lang="la">Juppiter,</quote> <trans><tr>who was worshipped at Anxur</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:799" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 799</bibl></cit>; v. Serv. ad h. l.— </sense><sense id="n2951.3" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Anxŭras</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">belonging to Anxur</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 38</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anydros: <entryFree id="n2952" type="main" key="a^nydros"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănydros</orth>, v. anhydros.</entryFree>
anytus: <entryFree id="n2953" type="main" key="A^ny^tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănytus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/anutos</foreign>, <sense id="n2953.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one of the accusers of Socrates</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 4, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aoede: <entryFree id="n2954" type="main" key="A^oede_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăoedē</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">trisyl.</orth>), <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n2954.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one of the first four Muses</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:21:54" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 21, 54</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aones: <entryFree id="n2955" type="main" key="A_o^nes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Āŏnes</orth>, <itype>um</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/aones</foreign>, <sense id="n2955.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Bœotian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aonas in montes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:6:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 6, 65</bibl></cit>.—Hence <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Bœotia</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. E. 6, 65</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aonia: <entryFree id="n2956" type="main" key="A_o^ni^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Āŏnĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)aoni/a</foreign>. <sense id="n2956.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A part of Bœotia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in which are the Aonian mountains</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Mount Helicon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and the fountain Aganippe</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. E. 6, 65</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">10, 12</bibl>.—Also in gen. for <hi rend="ital">Bœotia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:14:6" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 14, 6</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n2956.1" n="II" level="1"> Derivv. </sense><sense id="n2956.2" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Āŏnĭdes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <hi rend="ital">patr.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an Aonid</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Bœotian;</hi> of the Theban Eteocles, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:9:95" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 9, 95</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2956.3" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Āŏnis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <hi rend="ital">patr.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a Bœotian woman;</hi> hence, in the <number>plur.</number>: Aonides, <hi rend="ital">the Muses</hi>, as dwellers by Hellcon and Aganippe (cf. Aonia), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:333" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 333</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">6, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:7:59" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 7, 59</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2956.4" n="C" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Āŏnĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Aonia</hi>, i.e. <hi rend="ital">Bœotia</hi> (purely <usg type="style">poet.</usg>), <hi rend="ital">Aonian</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Bœotian</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:339" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 339</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 763</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">12, 24 al.</bibl>—Hence, Aonius vir, <hi rend="ital">Hercules</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a native of Thebes</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 112</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">juvenis,</quote> <trans><tr>Hippomenes</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:10:589" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 589</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">deus,</quote> <trans><tr>Bacchus</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:2:380" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. A. 2, 380</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aoniae, aquae,</quote> <trans><tr>Aganippe</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:456" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 3, 456</bibl></cit>.—Also, <hi rend="ital">an epithet of the Muses</hi> (cf. Aonis), <hi rend="ital">and of objects that have reference to them</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:245" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 245</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:4:10:39" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tr. 4, 10, 39</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:1:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 1, 1, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:3:547" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. A. 3, 547</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Achill. 5, 1, 113 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
aornos: <entryFree id="n2957" type="main" key="A^ornos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăornos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/aornos</foreign> (without birds) or <foreign lang="greek">h( *)/aornos li/mnh</foreign> (v. Strab. 1, 26; 5, 244 sqq.). <sense id="n2957.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Masc.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the Lake of Avernus in Campania</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Averno</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:242" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 242</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2957.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Fem.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2957.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A very high</hi>, <hi rend="ital">steep rock in India</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:11" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 8, 11</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2957.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A place in Epirus</hi>, Plin. prooem. 4.</sense></entryFree>
aous: <entryFree id="n2958" type="main" key="A^o_us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăōus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2958.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river of Illyria which falls into the Ionian Sea</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Vovussa</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Lao</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:5:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 32, 5, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 23, 26, § 145</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
apage: <entryFree id="n2959" type="greek" key="a^pa^ge^"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpăgĕ</orth>, the Greek <sense id="n2959.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">imp.</hi> <foreign lang="greek">a)/page</foreign>, used as <pos>interj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">away with thee! away! begone! avaunt!</hi> etc.; or also, <hi rend="ital">away with it! away! not surely!</hi> constr. with <case>acc.</case> (like o, ah, en, etc.) or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, also with sis (= si vis) (only in the comic poets or in epist. style; never used by Cic.). </sense><sense id="n2959.1" n="a" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">apage te a me,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:2:1:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 2, 1, 32</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:8:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cas. 2, 8, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:2:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 2, 65</bibl>; Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 51</bibl>, <cb n="APER" /> 64; Vatin. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">apage istas a me sorores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 3, 1, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:1:2:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. 1, 2, 33</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2959.2" n="b" level="4"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">Apage, non placet me etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:154" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 154</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">apage, haud nos id deceat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:1:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 2, 1, 17</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2959.3" n="c" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">sis</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">apage, sis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 15</bibl></cit>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:6:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 4, 6, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">apage, sis, Amor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:1:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 1, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">apage me, sis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 1, 19</bibl></cit>. Cf. Hand, Turs. I. p. 403 sq.</sense></entryFree>
apala: <entryFree id="n2960" type="greek" key="a^pa^la^"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpălă</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">hăp-</orth>), <sense id="n2960.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj. n. plur.</hi>, = <foreign lang="greek">a(pala/</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">soft</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tender</hi>, only with ova, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2003,001:7:17" default="NO"><author>Apic.</author> 7, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 2:7" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 2, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1011,001:Comp. 104" default="NO"><author>Scrib.</author> Comp. 104</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
apamea: <entryFree id="n2961" type="main" key="A^pa^me_a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpămēa</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-īa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)apa/meia</foreign>. <sense id="n2961.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">One of the most distinguished towns in Cœle-Syria</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the Orontes</hi>, in the Middle Ages, <hi rend="ital">Afamiah</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Famit</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Famieh</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 13</bibl> (where there is an allusion to the origin of the name), Cassiod. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:12:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 12, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 23, 19, § 81</bibl>; cf. Mann. Syr. 360.—</sense><sense id="n2961.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A town in Bithynia</hi>, earlier called Myrlea, now <hi rend="ital">Moudania</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:143" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 32, 40, § 143</bibl>; cf. Mann. Asia Min. 3, 560.—</sense><sense id="n2961.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A town in Phrygia the Great</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Dineir</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 2, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 29, 29, § 106</bibl>; cf. Mann. Asia Min. 3, 120 and 122.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n2961.3" n="IV" level="1"> Derivv. </sense><sense id="n2961.4" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpămēensis</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpă-mensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Apamea</hi> (in Phrygia Major): <cit><quote lang="la">forum Apamense,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">civitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:20:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 5, 20, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2961.5" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpă-mēnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, the same: <cit><quote lang="la">regio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:113" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 29, 31, § 113</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vinum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 14, 7, 9, § 75</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n2961.6" n="C" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpămēus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Apamea</hi> (in Bithynia); hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpămēi</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">its inhabitants</hi>, Trajan. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:10:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 10, 57</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aparctias: <entryFree id="n2962" type="greek" key="a^parcti^as"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăparctĭas</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)parkti)as</foreign>, <sense id="n2962.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the north wind</hi> (in pure Latin, septentrio), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 47, 46, § 119</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:22" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 22</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aparine: <entryFree id="n2963" type="greek" key="a^pa^ri_ne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpărīnē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)pari/nh</foreign>, <sense id="n2963.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cleavers</hi>: Galium aparine, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 5, 15, § 32</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
apathia: <entryFree id="n2964" type="greek" key="a^pa^thi_a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpăthīa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)pa/qeia</foreign>, <sense id="n2964.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">freedom from passion</hi> or <hi rend="ital">feeling</hi>, <hi rend="ital">insensibility</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the Stoic principle of morals</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Stoicism</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:12" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 12 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
apator: <entryFree id="n2965" type="greek" key="a^pa^to_r"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpătōr</orth>, <itype>ŏris</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)pa/twr</foreign>, <sense id="n2965.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">without father</hi>, Tert. Praescr. c. 53 Melchis.</sense></entryFree>
apaturius: <entryFree id="n2966" type="main" key="A^pa^tu_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpătūrĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2966.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a scene-painter of Allabanda</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:5:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 7, 5, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
apaturos: <entryFree id="n2967" type="main" key="A^pa^tu_ro^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpătūrŏs</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n2967.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a place on the Cimmerian Bosporus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with a temple of Venus Apaturia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 6, 6, § 18</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpă-tūrĭa</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a festival of Venus Apaturia</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Apol. 39</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ape: <entryFree id="n2968" type="gloss" key="ape"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ape</orth>: prohibe, compesce, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=22" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 22</bibl> Müll.; v. apio.</entryFree>
apeliotes: <entryFree id="n2969" type="greek" key="a^pe_li^o_tes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpēlĭōtes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)fhliw/ths</foreign>, Att., <foreign lang="greek">a)phliw/ths</foreign>, <sense id="n2969.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the east wind</hi> (in pure Lat., subsolanus), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:26:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 26, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 47, 46, § 119</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
apella: <entryFree id="n2970" type="main" key="A^pella"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpella</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <sense id="n2970.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of a Roman freedman</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 12, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 7, 25</bibl>; Planc. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 17</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2970.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of a credulous Jew who lived in the time of Horace;</hi> hence, appellative for <hi rend="ital">a credulous man</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:5:100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 5, 100</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
apelles: <entryFree id="n2971" type="main" key="A^pelles"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpelles</orth>, <itype>is</itype> (<case>voc.</case> Apella, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:5:4:101" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 5, 4, 101</bibl>, as if from the Doric <foreign lang="greek">*)apella=s</foreign>), <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)apellh=s</foreign>, <sense id="n2971.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a distinguished Greek painter in the time of Alexander the Great</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 10, 36, § 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:18:70" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 18, 70</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:2:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 2, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 1, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:8:11 al" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 8, 11 al.</bibl>—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpellēus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Apelles</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">opus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:7:83" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 7, 83</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tabulae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:2:22 al" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 2, 22 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
apello: <entryFree id="n2972" type="gloss" key="A^pello"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpello</orth>, v. Apollo.</entryFree>
apenninicola: <entryFree id="n2973" type="hapax" key="A_penni_ni^co^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Āpennīnĭcŏla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>comm.</gen> <etym>Apenninus-colo</etym>, <sense id="n2973.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a dweller among the Apennines</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:700" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 700</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
apenninigena: <entryFree id="n2974" type="main" key="A_penni_ni^ge^na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Āpennīnĭgĕna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>comm.</gen> <etym>Apenninus - gigno</etym>, <sense id="n2974.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">born upon the Apennines</hi>, <hi rend="ital">originating there</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:432" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 432</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> VI. Cons. Hon. 505</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
apenninus: <entryFree id="n2975" type="main" key="A_penni_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Āpennīnus</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">Appennīnus</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:703" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 703</bibl> Cod. Med.; <sense id="n2975.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">also APENINVS,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 204, 18</bibl></cit>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>from the Celtic penn, mountain - summit</etym>, <hi rend="ital">the mountainchain that passes through the length of Italy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the Apennines</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 7, § 48</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">conspicuous for height;</hi> hence, celsus Appenninus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:16:29" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 16, 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Appenninus nubifer,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:226" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 226</bibl></cit>.—Personified: <cit><quote lang="la">gaudetque nivali Vertice se attollens pater Appenninus ad auras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:703" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 703</bibl></cit>; cf. Mann. Ital. 1, 264 sq.</sense></entryFree>
aper: <entryFree id="n2976" type="main" key="a^per1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăper</orth>, <itype>pri</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>cf. old Germ. Ebar; <cb n="APER" /> Germ. Eber; Angl.-Sax. bār = aper, verres; Engl. boar; cf. Lat. caper, with change of meaning, and the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">ka/pros</foreign></etym>, <sense id="n2976.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a wild boar.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2976.1" n="I. A." level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:282" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 282</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">9, 192</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">10, 550</bibl>; 10, 715; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:7:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 7, 29</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">10, 56</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:324 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 1, 324 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aper Erymanthius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:22:50" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 22, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Arcadius,</quote> <trans><tr>the Erymanthian boar slain by Her cules</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:9:104" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 9, 104</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aper de silvā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:79:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 79, 14</bibl></cit>.—Among the Romans a delicacy, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:1:140" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 1, 140</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Masc.</hi> form used of the female in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 8:47, p. 183" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 8, 47, p. 183</bibl> Müll., though Pliny had formed <hi rend="ital">apra</hi>, q. v.—</sense><sense id="n2976.2" n="B" level="2"> Prov. </sense><sense id="n2976.3" n="1" level="3"> Uno saltu duos apros capere, <hi rend="ital">to kill two birds with one stone</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:8:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 2, 8, 40</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n2976.4" n="2" level="3"> Apros immittere liquidis fontibus, for something perverse, inconsiderate, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:2:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 2, 59</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2976.5" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2976.6" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A standard of the Roman legions</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 4, 5, § 16</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2976.7" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A kind of fish</hi>, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> p. 486</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">is, qui aper vocatur in Acheloo amne, grunnitum habet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:267" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 51, 112, § 267</bibl></cit> Jan.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2977" type="main" key="A^per2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăper</orth>, <itype>pri</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2977.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman cognomen</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Or. 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Lampr.</author> Commod. 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 692, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aperantia: <entryFree id="n2978" type="main" key="A^pe^ranti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpĕrantĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)aperanti/a</foreign>, <sense id="n2978.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small province in Thessaly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">south of the Dolopians</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 36, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:3" default="NO" valid="yes">38, 3</bibl>; cf. Mann. Greece, 39.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpĕrantĭi</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">its inhabitants</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:43:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 43, 22</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aperibilis: <entryFree id="n2979" type="main" key="a^pe^ri^bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpĕrĭbĭlis</orth>, v. apertibilis.</entryFree>
aperio: <entryFree id="n2980" type="main" key="a^pe^ri^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpĕrĭo</orth>, <itype>ĕrŭi, ertum, 4</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (<sense id="n2980.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fut.</hi> aperibo, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:2:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 4, 2, 50</bibl>; Pompon. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 506, 30</bibl>) [ab-pario, to get from, take away from, i.e. to uncover, like the opp. operio, from obpario, to get for, to put upon, i. e. to cover; this is the old explanation, and is received by Corssen, Ausspr. I. p. 653; II. p. 410, and by Vanicek, p. 503], <hi rend="ital">to uncover</hi>, <hi rend="ital">make</hi> or <hi rend="ital">lay bare.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2980.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">patinas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:3:2:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 3, 2, 51</bibl></cit>: apertae surae, Turp. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 236, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">apertis lateribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0646,001:ib. p. 236:26" default="NO"><author>Sisenn.</author> ib. p. 236, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">capite aperto esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:ib. p. 236:25" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> ib. p. 236, 25</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">p. 236, 28: ut corporis partes quaedam aperiantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:35:129" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 35, 129</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">caput aperuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 31</bibl></cit>; Sall. H. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 236, 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">capita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 6, 17, § 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aperto pectore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:339" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 339</bibl></cit>; and <usg type="style">poet.</usg> transf. to the person: <cit><quote lang="la">apertae pectora matres,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:13:688" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 13, 688</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ramum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:406 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 406 al.</bibl></cit>—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to make visible</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to show</hi>, <hi rend="ital">reveal</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">dispulsā nebulā diem aperuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 26, 17</bibl></cit> (cf. just before: <cit><quote lang="la">densa nebula campos circa intexit): dies faciem victoriae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lux aperuit bellum ducemque belli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">novam aciem dies aperuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">his unda dehiscens Terram aperit,</quote> <trans><tr>opens to view</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 107</bibl></cit>.—From the intermediate idea of making visible, </sense><sense id="n2980.2" n="II" level="1"> Metaph. </sense><sense id="n2980.3" n="A. 1." level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To unclose</hi>, <hi rend="ital">open</hi>: aperto ex ostio Alti Acheruntis, Poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:16:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 16, 37</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aperite aliquis ostium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:4:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 4, 26</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 35</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">forem aperi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:2:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 2, 1, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:2:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 2, 2, 52</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:457" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 457</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:82" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 82</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">januas carceris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:5:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 5, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fenestram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:8:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Gen. 8, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">liquidas vias,</quote> <trans><tr>to open the liquid way</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:373" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 373</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:884" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 884</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sucum venis fundere apertis,</quote> <trans><tr>to pour out moisture from its open veins</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:812" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 812</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">saccum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:42:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 42, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">os,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 22, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">labia, ib. Job, 11, 5: oculos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:9:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 9, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accepi fasciculum, in quo erat epistula Piliae: abstuli, aperui, legi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 11 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 13</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">6, 3: aperire librum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:5:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Apoc. 5, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">20, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">testamentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:177" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 52, 53, § 177</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">testamentum resignare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 7, 9</bibl></cit>); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:83" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 83</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:17" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Aug. 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sigillum aperire,</quote> <trans><tr>to break</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:6:3 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Apoc. 6, 3 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferro iter aperiundum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 58:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 58, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">locum ... asylum,</quote> <trans><tr>to make it an asylum</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">subterraneos specus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navigantibus maria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:122" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 47, 47, § 122</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arbor florem aperit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 12, 11, 23, § 40</bibl></cit> et saep.: aperire parietem, <hi rend="ital">to open a wall</hi>, in order to put a door or window in it, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:8:2:40" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 8, 2, 40</bibl>: alicui oculos aperire, <hi rend="ital">to give sight to</hi> (after the Heb.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:9:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Joan. 9, 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">9, 14 al.</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">aures aperire,</quote> <trans><tr>to restore hearing to</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:7:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Marc. 7, 35</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2980.4" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec ita claudenda est res familiaris, ut eam benignitas aperire non possit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:15:54" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 15, 54</bibl></cit>: amicitiae fores. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 13, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">multus apertus cursus ad laudem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:14:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 14, 6 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tibi virtus tua reditum ad tuos aperuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 6, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">philosophiae fontes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:3:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 3, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:31:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 31, 85</bibl> et saep.: alicujus oculos aperire, <hi rend="ital">to open one's eyes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">make him discern</hi> (after the Heb.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 3, 5</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:26:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 26, 18</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">alicujus cor aperire,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 16, 14</bibl></cit>: ventus<pb n="136" /> <cb n="APER" />  incendio viam aperuit, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">occasionem ad invadendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 53</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 9, 27</bibl>: si hanc fenestram aperueritis (i.e. <hi rend="ital">if you enter upon the way of complaint</hi>), nihil aliud agi sinetis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:28" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 28</bibl> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:1:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 1, 72</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quantam fenestram ad nequitiem patefeceris!): quia aperuisset gentibus ostium fidei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:14:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 14, 27</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Col. 4, 3</bibl>.— So of the new year, <hi rend="ital">to open it</hi>, i.e. <hi rend="ital">begin</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">annum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:217" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 217</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">contigit ergo privatis aperire annum (since the consul entered upon his office the first of January),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:58:4" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 58, 4</bibl></cit> Gierig and Schaef.—So also of a school, <hi rend="ital">to establish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">set up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">begin</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">open it</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Dionysius tyrannus Corinthi dicitur ludum aperuisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 18</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,004:16" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Gram. 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,004:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rhet. 4</bibl>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">fuste aperire caput,</quote> <trans>i.e. <tr>to cleave</tr>, <tr>split the head</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:9:98" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 9, 98</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2980.5" n="B" level="2"> Aperire locum (populum, gentes, etc.), <hi rend="ital">to lay open a place</hi>, <hi rend="ital">people</hi>, etc., i.e. <hi rend="ital">to open an entrance to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">render accessible</hi> (cf. patefacio); <cit><quote lang="la">most freq. in the histt., esp. in Tacitus: qui aperuerint armis orbem terrarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 52</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:4" default="NO" valid="yes">42, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Syriam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnes terras fortibus viris natura aperuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 4, 64</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">novas gentes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gentes ac reges,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Britanniam tamdiu clausam aperit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:3:6:4" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 3, 6, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:1:465" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 1, 465</bibl> Cort.: <cit><quote lang="la">Eoas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:4:352" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 352</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pelagus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:1:169" default="NO"><author>Val.
