Fl.</author> 1, 169</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2980.6" n="C" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> to mental objects, <hi rend="ital">to disclose something unknown</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to unveil</hi>, <hi rend="ital">reveal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">make known</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unfold</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to prove</hi>, <hi rend="ital">demonstrate;</hi> or gen. <hi rend="ital">to explain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">recount</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">occulta quaedam et quasi involuta aperiri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:9:30" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 9, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">explicanda est saepe verbis mens nostra de quāque re atque involutae rei notitia definiendo aperienda est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:33:116" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 33, 116</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alicui scripturas aperire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:24:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Luc. 24, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tua probra aperibo omnia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:2:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 4, 2, 50</bibl></cit>: ne exspectetis argumentum fabulae; <cit><quote lang="la">hi partem aperient,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:prol. 23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. prol. 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non quo aperiret sententiam suam, sed etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:18:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 18, 84</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eo praesente conjurationem aperit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 40:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 40, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naturam et mores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 53</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 45:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 45, 1</bibl>; 47, 1; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 33:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> J. 33, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">lux fugam hostium aperuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aperiri error poterat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 26, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">casus aperire futuros,</quote> <trans><tr>to disclose the future</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:559" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 559</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">futura aperit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 4</bibl></cit>.—So also, se aperire or aperiri, <hi rend="ital">to reveal one's true disposition</hi>, <hi rend="ital">character</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tum coacti necessario se aperiunt,</quote> <trans><tr>show themselves in their true light</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 1, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">studio aperimur in ipso,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:3:371" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 3, 371</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exspectandum, dum se ipsa res aperiret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,004:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Paus. 3, 7</bibl></cit>; Quint. prooem. § 3.—Sometimes constr. with <case>acc.</case> and <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>, a <hi rend="ital">rel.-clause</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">de</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum jam directae in se prorae hostes appropinquare aperuissent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 44, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">domino navis, quis sit, aperit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,002:8:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Them. 8, 6</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:13:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eum. 13, 3</bibl>: de clementiā, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 2, 31</bibl>.—In a gen. sense (freq. in epistt.) in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 1, 2</bibl>: de Oppio factum est, ut volui, et maxime, quod DCCC. aperuisti, <hi rend="ital">you promised</hi>, i.e. <hi rend="ital">that it should be paid to him</hi> (= ostendisti te daturum, Manut.); cf. <cit><quote lang="la">the more definite expression: de Oppio bene curāsti, quod ei DCCC. exposuisti,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 4, 3</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpertus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">P. a.;</hi> pr., <hi rend="ital">opened;</hi> hence, <hi rend="ital">open</hi>, <hi rend="ital">free.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2980.7" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2980.8" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Without covering</hi>, <hi rend="ital">open</hi>, <hi rend="ital">uncovered</hi> (opp. tectus): <cit><quote lang="la">naves apertae,</quote> <trans><tr>without deck</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 40</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 22 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:21:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 32, 21, 14</bibl>: centum tectae naves et quinquaginta leviores apertae, et saep.; v. navis.—Also, <hi rend="ital">without covering</hi> or <hi rend="ital">defence</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unprotected</hi>, <hi rend="ital">exposed</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">locus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 84</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, of the sky, <hi rend="ital">clear</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cloudless</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">caelo invectus aperto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:155" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 155</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aether,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 587</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aperta serena prospicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:393" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 1, 393</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2980.9" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Unclosed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">open</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not shut</hi> (opp. clausus): <cit><quote lang="la">Janua cum per se transpectum praebet apertum,</quote> <trans><tr>since this affords an open view through it</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:272" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 272</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oculi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:339" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 339</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oculorum lumine aperto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1139" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 1139</bibl></cit> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil tam clausum, neque tam reconditum, quod non istius cupiditati apertissimum promptissimumque esset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">caelum patens atque apertum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 1</bibl></cit> (diff. from 1.); so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:693" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 693</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vidit caelos apertos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:1:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Marc. 1, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">apertus et propatulus locus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">iter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">apertior aditus ad moenia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 9, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">campi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 38, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per apertum limitem (viae),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 21</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:285" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 285</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">fenestrae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,056:6:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Dan. 6, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ostia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 13, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:527" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 527</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:8:165" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 165</bibl>; 11, 555 et saep. —<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, of a battle: nec aperti copia Martis Ulla fuit, <hi rend="ital">an action in the open field</hi>, Ov. <cb n="APER" /> M. 13, 208.—Very freq. <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpertum</orth>, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">that which is open</hi>, <hi rend="ital">free; an open</hi>, <hi rend="ital">clear space</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in aperto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:604" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 604</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per apertum fugientes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> C, 3, 12, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">impetum ex aperto facerent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">castra in aperto posita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1, 33</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 22, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">volantem in aperto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 8, 9, § 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in aperta prodeunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 8, 32, 50, § 117</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">disjecit naves in aperta Oceani,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 23</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2980.10" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2980.11" n="1. a." level="1"> Opp. to that which is concealed, covered, dark, <hi rend="ital">open</hi>, <hi rend="ital">clear</hi>, <hi rend="ital">plain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">evident</hi>, <hi rend="ital">manifest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unobstructed</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam nihil aegrius est quam res secernere apertas ab dubiis,</quote> <trans><tr>nothing is</tr>, <tr>indeed</tr>, <tr>more difficult than to separate things that are evident from those that are doubtful</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:467" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 467</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:596" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 596</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:915" default="NO" valid="yes">1, 915</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1062" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 1062</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum illum ex occultis insidiis in apertum latrocinium conjecimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">simultates partim obscurae, partim apertae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:chapter=24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Manil. 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid enim potest esse tam apertum tamque perspicuum?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:2:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 2, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid rem apertam suspectam facimus?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:41:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 41, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non furtim, sed vi aperta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 25, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">apertus animi motus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:3:21" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 3, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">invidia in occulto, adulatio in aperto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 4</bibl></cit> et saep.—So, in rhet., of <hi rend="ital">clear</hi>, <hi rend="ital">intelligible</hi> discourse: <cit><quote lang="la">multo apertius ad intellegendum est, si, etc. ... apertam enim narrationem tam esse oportet quam, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:80:328" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 80, 328</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 1, 20</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n2980.12" n="b" level="4"> Esp. as <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: in aperto esse, </sense><sense id="n2980.13" n="(a)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">To be clear</hi>, <hi rend="ital">evident</hi>, <hi rend="ital">well known</hi>, <hi rend="ital">notorious</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">e)n tw=| fanerw=| ei)=nai</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad cognoscendum omnia illustria magis magisque in aperto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 5, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2980.14" n="(b)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">To be easily practicable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">easy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">facile</hi> (the figure taken from an open field or space): <cit><quote lang="la">agere memoratu digna pronum magisque in aperto erat,</quote> <trans><tr>there was a greater inclination and a more open way to</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hostes aggredi in aperto foret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 3, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vota virtusque in aperto omniaque prona victoribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 33</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2980.15" n="2" level="3"> Of character, <hi rend="ital">without dissimulation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">open</hi>, <hi rend="ital">frank</hi>, <hi rend="ital">candid</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">animus apertus et simplex,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 1, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:13:57" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 13, 57</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pectus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:26:97" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 26, 97</bibl></cit>. —Hence, ironically: ut semper fuit apertissimus, <hi rend="ital">as he has always been very open</hi>, <hi rend="ital">frank</hi> (for <hi rend="ital">impudent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">shameless</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 35</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpertē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">openly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">clearly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">plainly.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2980.16" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">tam aperte irridens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:8:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 5, 8, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab illo aperte tecte quicquid est datum, libenter accepi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:14:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 14, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:12:38" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 12, 38</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:18:67" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Am. 18, 67</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum Fidenae aperte descissent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aperte quod venale habet ostendit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:2:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 2, 83</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aperte revelari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:2:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Reg. 2, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non jam secretis colloquiis, sed aperte fremere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aperte adulari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:26:99" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Am. 26, 99</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aperte mentiri,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 6, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aperte pugnare, id. ap. Aquil. Rom. 10: aperte immundus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:13:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Lev. 13, 26</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ipsum dolorem hic tulit paulo apertius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:chapter=34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 34</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 16, 3, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:1:11" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 1, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab his proconsuli venenum inter epulas datum est apertius quam ut fallerent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 1</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hinc empta apertissime praetura,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 100</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">equite Romano per te apertissime interfecto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,021:chapter=30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Har. Resp. 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">largiri,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praedari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=130" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 1, 130</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2980.17" n="II" level="1"> Esp. of what is set forth in words or writing, <hi rend="ital">plainly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">clearly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">freely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">without reserve</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nempe ergo aperte vis quae restant me loqui?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:2:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 2, 24</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:4:3:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 4, 3, 49</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aperte indicat (lex) posse rationem habere non praesentis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,059:1:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> ad Brut. 1, 5, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Non tu istuc mihi dictura aperte es, quicquid est?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">narrare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:3:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 4, 3, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">scribere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:7:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 7, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:5:43" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 5, 43</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Planius atque apertius dicam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,003:14:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Com. 14, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">distinguere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:3:6:45" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 3, 6, 45</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">istius injurias quam apertissime vobis planissimeque explicare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:64:156" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 64, 156</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquid apertissime ostendere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:12:11" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 12, 11</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aperta: <entryFree id="n2981" type="gloss" key="A^perta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăperta</orth>, <sense id="n2981.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a surname of Apollo</hi>: quia patente (i.e. apertā) cortinā responsa ab eo darentur, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=22" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 22</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
apertibilis: <entryFree id="n2982" type="main" key="a^perti^bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpertĭbĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aperio</etym>, <sense id="n2982.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">opening</hi>, <hi rend="ital">aperient</hi>, med. t., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Acut. 3:3" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Acut. 3, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:3:4" default="NO">3, 4</bibl>, where <hi rend="ital">aperibilis</hi> also is read.</sense></entryFree>
apertio: <entryFree id="n2983" type="main" key="a^perti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpertĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2983.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an opening</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unfolding</hi> (only ante- and post-class.). </sense><sense id="n2983.1" n="a" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">floris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 1, 6, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">templi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 11, p. 266, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,034:20:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Eccli. 20, 15</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Ephes. 6, 19</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2983.2" n="b" level="4"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum periculo introitur recenti apertione,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1</bibl></cit>, <cb n="APHI" /> 63: <cit><quote lang="la">apertio,</quote> <trans><tr>the solemn opening of a temple</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 4, 301</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aperto: <entryFree id="n2984" type="hapax" key="a^perto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăperto</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <sense id="n2984.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. freq.</hi> [id.], <hi rend="ital">to lay bare</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quaeso, cur apertas brachium?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 5, 5, 12</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
apertor: <entryFree id="n2985" type="hapax" key="a^pertor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpertor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2985.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">he that opens</hi>, <hi rend="ital">begins</hi> (cf. aperio, II. A.): <cit><quote lang="la">baptismi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 2, 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
apertum: <entryFree id="n2986" type="main" key="a^pertum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpertum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, v. aperio.</entryFree>
apertura: <entryFree id="n2987" type="main" key="a^pertu_ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpertūra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aperio</etym> (only post Aug.). <sense id="n2987.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An opening</hi> (abstr.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 4, 6 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:28:5:3" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 28, 5, 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2987.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An opening</hi> (concr.), <hi rend="ital">aperture</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a hole</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:5:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 5, 5</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:10:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 10, 9</bibl>: <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Amos, 4, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">9, 11</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
apertus: <entryFree id="n2988" type="main" key="a^pertus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpertus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, from aperio.</entryFree>
apex: <entryFree id="n2989" type="main" key="a^pex"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpex</orth>, <itype>ĭcis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>etym. acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 10, 270</bibl>, and Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=18" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 18</bibl> Müll., from apo, to join to, whence aptus; cf. Van. Etym. p. 33</etym>, <sense id="n2989.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the extreme end of a thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the point</hi>, <hi rend="ital">summit</hi>, <hi rend="ital">top</hi> (syn.: cacumen, summa, fastigium, culmen, vertex); hence, </sense><sense id="n2989.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">the small rod at the top of the flamen's cap</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wound round with wool</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 2, 683</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">10, 270</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n2989.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2989.3" n="A" level="2"> (As pars pro toto.) <hi rend="ital">The conical cap of the flamen</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ornamented with this rod</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">QVEI. APICEM. INSIGNE. DIALIS. FLAMINIS. GESISTEI, Epitaph. Scip. Grotef. 2, 299: apicem dialem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">apex e capite prolapsus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:1:1" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 1, 1</bibl></cit>, n. 4.—Hence, of the <hi rend="ital">priesthood</hi> itself: homo honestus non apice insignis, Sen. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 17, 6</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2989.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Any hat</hi> or <hi rend="ital">helmet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a crown</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab aquilā Tarquinio apicem impositum putent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">regum apices,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:21:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 21, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ardet apex capiti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:270" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 270</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 683</bibl>.—Of birds, <hi rend="ital">the crest</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 37, 44, § 121</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2989.5" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A projecting point</hi> or <hi rend="ital">summit.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2989.6" n="1" level="3"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, of trees: <cit><quote lang="la">lauri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 66</bibl></cit>.—Of a headland: <cit><quote lang="la">sublimis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:12:72" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 12, 72</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">montis apex,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:12:709" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 12, 709</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Judith, 7, 3</bibl>.—Of the point of a sickle, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:4:25:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 4, 25, 1</bibl>.—Of the summit of a flame, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:279" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 279</bibl> et saep.—</sense><sense id="n2989.7" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">the highest ornament</hi> or <hi rend="ital">honor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the crown of a thing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">apex est senectutis auctoritas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:17:60" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 17, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hinc apicem Fortuna sustulit, hic posuisse gaudet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:34:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 34, 14</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2989.8" n="D. 1." level="1"> In gram., <hi rend="ital">the long mark over a vowel</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:7:2" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 7, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:4:10" default="NO">1, 4, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:5:23" default="NO">1, 5, 23</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">Victor. p. 2469 P.—Hence, trop.: nullum apicem quaestionis praetermittere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 3 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n2989.9" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The forms</hi> or <hi rend="ital">outlines of the letters</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">litterarum apices,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:13:30:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 13, 30, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:17:9:12" default="NO">17, 9, 12</bibl>.—Hence (per synecdochen), </sense><sense id="n2989.10" n="E" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A letter</hi> or <hi rend="ital">any other writing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">apicum oblator,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 6, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Augusti apices,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>rescripts</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 2, 8, 6 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n2989.11" n="F" level="1"> Of the point or apex of a Hebrew letter, put fig. for <hi rend="ital">the least particle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tittle</hi> (eccl. Lat.; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">h( kerai/a</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">iota unum aut unus apex non praeteribit a lege,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:5:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 5, 18</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:16:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Luc. 16, 17</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
apexabo: <entryFree id="n2990" type="main" key="a^pexa^bo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpexăbo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>apex</etym>, <sense id="n2990.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of sausage</hi> (perh. only in the two foll. examples), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=111" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 111</bibl> Müll.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 7, p. 229</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aphaca: <entryFree id="n2991" type="greek" key="a^pha^ca"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăphăca</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)fa/kh</foreign>. <sense id="n2991.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A kind of pulse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">field</hi> or <hi rend="ital">chick-pea</hi>: Lathyrus aphaca, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 5, 21, § 38</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2991.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A wild plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the common dandelion</hi>: Leontodon taraxacum, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 15, 52, § 89</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aphaea: <entryFree id="n2992" type="main" key="A^phaea"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăphaea</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)afai/a</foreign>, <sense id="n2992.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an epithet of Britomartis</hi> (q. v.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Verg.</author> Cir. 303</bibl>, ubi v. Wagner.</sense></entryFree>
aphaerema: <entryFree id="n2993" type="greek" key="a^phaere^ma"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăphaerĕma</orth>, <itype>ătis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)fai/rema</foreign>, <sense id="n2993.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a coarse kind of grits</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 11, 29, § 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aphaeresis: <entryFree id="n2994" type="greek" key="a^phaere^sis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăphaerĕsis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)fai/resis</foreign>, a gram. fig., <sense id="n2994.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the dropping of a letter</hi> or <hi rend="ital">syllable at the beginning of a word</hi> (e. g. ruere for eruere, temnere for contemnere, etc.), Prob. p. 1438 P.; Don. p. 1772 ib.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 248</bibl> ib.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 1, 546</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 669 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
aphareus: <entryFree id="n2995" type="main" key="A^pha^reus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăphăreus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">trisyl.</orth>), <itype>ĕi</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)afareu/s</foreign>. <sense id="n2995.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A king of the Messenians;</hi> hence his sons Lynceus and Idas are called Ăphărēïa proles, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:304" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 304</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2995.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A centaur</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:341 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 341 sq.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
aphe: <entryFree id="n2996" type="main" key="a^phe_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăphē</orth>, v. haphe.</entryFree>
aphesas: <entryFree id="n2997" type="main" key="A^phe^sa_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăphĕsās</orth>, <itype>antos</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)afe/sas</foreign>, <sense id="n2997.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a mountain in Peloponnesus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">near Nemea</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Fouka</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:3:460" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 3, 460</bibl> (in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 5, 9, § 17</bibl>, called Apesantus, Jan).</sense></entryFree>
aphidnae: <entryFree id="n2998" type="main" key="A^phidnae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăphidnae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/afidnai</foreign>, <sense id="n2998.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small place in Attica</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Hippol. 24" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Hippol. 24</bibl>.—In <number>sing.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aphidna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:5:708" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 5, 708</bibl></cit>; cf. Mann Gr. p. 335. <pb n="137" /> <cb n="APIC" /></sense></entryFree>
aphractus: <entryFree id="n2999" type="greek" key="a_^phractus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā^phractus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">ā^phractum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/fraktos</foreign> (uncovered, sc. <foreign lang="greek">nau=s</foreign>, hence), <sense id="n2999.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a long vessel without a deck</hi> (in pure Latin, navis aperta; <cit><quote lang="la">only in Cic.): Navigavimus tardius propter aphractorum Rhodiorum imbecillitatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:13:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 13, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">detraxit viginti ipsos dies aphractus Rhodiorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 8, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aphracta Rhodiorum habebam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 11, 4</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 12, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aphrodes: <entryFree id="n3000" type="greek" key="a_^phro_des"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā^phrōdes</orth>, <sense id="n3000.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj. comm.</hi>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)frw/dhs</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">foamy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">like foam</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mecon,</quote> <trans><tr>a wild poppy</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 12, 93, § 119</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 53</bibl> (in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:207" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 19, 79, § 207</bibl>, called aphron).</sense></entryFree>
aphrodisia: <entryFree id="n3001" type="greek" key="A_^phro^di_si^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^phrŏdīsĭa</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)afrodi/sia</foreign>, <sense id="n3001.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a festival of Venus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:1:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 1, 62</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 2, 44</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aphrodisiace: <entryFree id="n3002" type="greek" key="a_^phro^di_si^a^ce_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā^phrŏdīsĭăcē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)frodisiakh/</foreign>, <sense id="n3002.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a precious stone of a reddish-white color</hi>, unknown to us, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:148" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 10, 54, § 148</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aphrodisias: <entryFree id="n3003" type="main" key="A_^phro^di_si^a^s1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^phrŏdīsĭăs</orth>, <itype>ădis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*afrodisia/s</foreign>. <sense id="n3003.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A region in Asiatic Æolis</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:122" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 30, 32, § 122</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n3003.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A town and promontory in Caria</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the Mœander</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Geira</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 28, 29, § 104</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n3003.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An island near Gades</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:120" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 22, 36, § 120</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n3003.3" n="IV" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An island in the Persian Gulf</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Kaish</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 25, 28, § 111</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n3004" type="main" key="a_^phro^di_si^as2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā^phrŏdīsĭas</orth> = acorus, q. v.; perh. <sense id="n3004.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sweet-flag</hi>, <hi rend="ital">calamus</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aphrodisium: <entryFree id="n3005" type="main" key="A_^phro^di_si^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^phrŏdīsĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)afrodi/sion</foreign>. <sense id="n3005.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A town on the coast of Latium</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in the province of Lavinium</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with a renowned temple of Venus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which was destroyed as early as the time of Pliny</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 9, § 57</bibl>; cf. Mann. Ital. 1, 617; Müll. Roms Camp. 2, 271.—</sense><sense id="n3005.1" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^phrŏdīsĭum</orth> <itype>promontorium</itype>, <hi rend="ital">a promontory in Thessaly</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 31, 2, 7, § 10</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n3005.2" n="III" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^phrŏdīsĭum</orth> <itype>flumen</itype>, <hi rend="ital">a river in Caria</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 31, 2, 7, § 10</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aphron: <entryFree id="n3006" type="main" key="a_^phron"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā^phron</orth>, v. aphrodes.</entryFree>
aphronitrum: <entryFree id="n3007" type="greek" key="a_^phro^ni_^trum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā^phrŏnī^trum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)fro/nitron</foreign>, <sense id="n3007.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the efflorescence of saltpetre</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 31, 10, 46, § 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:58" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 14, 58</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aphthae: <entryFree id="n3008" type="greek" key="aphthae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aphthae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/fqai</foreign>, <sense id="n3008.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an eruption in the mouth</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the thrush</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Marc. Emp.</author> 11</bibl> (in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:6:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 6, 11</bibl>, written as Greek).</sense></entryFree>
aphya: <entryFree id="n3009" type="main" key="a^phy^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăphya</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-ē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)fu/h</foreign>, <sense id="n3009.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small fish</hi>, usu. called apua, acc. to some the <hi rend="ital">anchovy</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 32, 11, 53, § 145</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 31, 8, 44, § 95</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
apia: <entryFree id="n3010" type="main" key="A^pi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)api/a</foreign>, <sense id="n3010.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an old name of the Peloponnesus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 4, 5, § 9</bibl> (v. aqua <hi rend="ital">init.</hi>).</sense></entryFree>
apiacus: <entryFree id="n3011" type="main" key="a^pi^a^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpĭăcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>apium</etym>, <sense id="n3011.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">relating to parsley</hi>, <hi rend="ital">similar to parsley</hi>: brassica, Cato ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:136" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 8, 41, § 136</bibl> Jan; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 157, 2</bibl> (others read in the first passage <hi rend="ital">apianam</hi>, in the latter <hi rend="ital">apia</hi>).</sense></entryFree>
apianus: <entryFree id="n3012" type="main" key="a^pi^a_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>apis</etym>, <sense id="n3012.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">belonging to bees</hi>, <hi rend="ital">of bees.</hi> </sense><sense id="n3012.1" n="I" level="1"> <pos>Adj.</pos>, uva, loved by bees, <hi rend="ital">the muscatel</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 2, 4, § 3</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:39:3" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 12, 39, 3</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">vitis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:2:17" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 2, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vinum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:47:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 12, 47, 6</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n3012.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpĭāna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (sc. herba), <hi rend="ital">chamomile</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 23</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
apiarius: <entryFree id="n3013" type="main" key="a^pi^a_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpĭārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n3013.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">relating to bees;</hi> only <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, </sense><sense id="n3013.1" n="I" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpĭārĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a bee-keeper</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 10, 31, § 56</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n3013.2" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpĭ-ārĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a bee-house</hi>, <hi rend="ital">beehive</hi> (prob. first introd. by Columella into the written lang.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:20:8" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 20, 8</bibl>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:5:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 9, 5, 1</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:3:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 9, 3, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:5:6" default="NO">9, 5, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:7:1" default="NO">9, 7, 1</bibl>; 9, 12, 4 al.</sense></entryFree>
apiastellum: <entryFree id="n3014" type="main" key="a^pi^astellum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpĭastellum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <sense id="n3014.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The plant</hi> batrachion or herba scelerata, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 8</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n3014.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The plant</hi> bryonia, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 66</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
apiastra: <entryFree id="n3015" type="gloss" key="a^pi^astra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpĭastra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>apis</etym>, <sense id="n3015.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a bird that lies in wait for bees</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a bee-eater</hi>, commonly called merops (for apiaster or merops apiaster, Linn.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. G. 4, 14</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
apiastrum: <entryFree id="n3016" type="main" key="a^pi^astrum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpĭastrum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>. <sense id="n3016.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Wild-parsley</hi>: Selinum palustre, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 12, 41, § 70</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:8:12" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 9, 8, 12</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n3016.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Balm</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a plant of which bees are fond</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">melissophyllon,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:16:10" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 16, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 9, 29, § 53</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
apiatus: <entryFree id="n3017" type="main" key="a^pi^a_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpĭātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype> <etym>apium</etym>. <sense id="n3017.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Boiled with parsley</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aqua,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Theod. Prisc.</author> 2, 2</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n3017.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Like a parsley-leaf</hi>, <hi rend="ital">crisped</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mensa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 13, 15, 30, § 96</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
apica: <entryFree id="n3018" type="greek" key="a^pi_ca"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpīca</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (sc. ovis) [perh. <foreign lang="greek">a)peikw/s</foreign>, unfit, unnatural], <sense id="n3018.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a sheep that has no wool on the belly</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:2:3" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 2, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:198" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 48, 75, § 198</bibl>; Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=25" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 25</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
apicatus: <entryFree id="n3019" type="hapax" key="a^pi^ca_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpĭcātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, as if from apico [apex], <sense id="n3019.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adorned with the priest's cap</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Dialis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:397" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 3, 397</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
apicius: <entryFree id="n3020" type="main" key="a^pi_ci^us1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpīcĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>apis</etym>, <sense id="n3020.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sought by bees</hi>, <hi rend="ital">liked by bees;</hi> hence, <hi rend="ital">sweet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dainty</hi>, = <cb n="APIS" /> apianus, q. v.: <cit><quote lang="la">uvae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 24, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:58" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 58</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 4, 5, § 46</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 2, 16</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpīcĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, sc. vinum, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 6, 5</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:25" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 25</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n3021" type="main" key="A^pi_ci^us2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpīcĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <sense id="n3021.0" n="I. A." level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A notorious epicure under Augustus and Tiberius</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:133" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 48, 68, § 133</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 1</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n3021.1" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The title of a Latin book on cookery</hi>, <hi rend="ital">yet extant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in ten books</hi>, whose author is unknown, v. Bähr, <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> Gesch. p. 521; Teuffel, Rom. <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> § 278, 4.—</sense><sense id="n3021.2" n="II" level="1"> Deriv.: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpīcĭ-ānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Apicius</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">coctura,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:143" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 8, 41, § 143</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">patina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2003,001:4:2" default="NO"><author>Apic.</author> 4, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">condimenta,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Anim. 33</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
apicula: <entryFree id="n3022" type="main" key="a^pi^cu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpĭcŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>apis</etym>, <sense id="n3022.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a little bee</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:1:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 1, 1, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 21, 21, § 85</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1248,001:Ep. ad Ver. 8" default="NO"><author>Fronto</author> Ep. ad Ver. 8</bibl> Mai.</sense></entryFree>
apiculum: <entryFree id="n3023" type="gloss" key="a^pi^cu^lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpĭcŭlum</orth>: filum, quo flamines velatum apicem gerunt, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=23" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 23</bibl> Müll.; cf. apex, I.</entryFree>
apidanus: <entryFree id="n3024" type="main" key="A_pi^da^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Āpĭdănus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)apidano/s</foreign>, <sense id="n3024.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in Thessaly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which</hi>, <hi rend="ital">uniting with the Enipeus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">flows into the Peneus</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Fersaliti</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:580" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 580</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 228</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:6:373" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 6, 373</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:1:357" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 1, 357</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
apina: <entryFree id="n3025" type="main" key="A^pi^na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăpĭna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n3025.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a poor and small town in Apulia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:144" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 11, 16, § 144</bibl>.—Hence, in the <number>plur.</number>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpĭnae</orth>, prov. (as tricae, q. v.), <hi rend="ital">trifles</hi>, <hi rend="ital">worthless things</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">apinae tricaeque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:1:7" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 14, 1, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:1:113:2" default="NO">1, 113, 2</bibl> (some regard this form as from <foreign lang="greek">a)fanh/s</foreign>, obscure, of no account).</sense></entryFree>
apio: <entryFree id="n3026" type="main" key="a^pi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpĭo</orth>, v. apo.</entryFree>
apiolae: <entryFree id="n3027" type="main" key="Apio^lae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Apiŏlae</orth>, v. Appiolae.</entryFree>
apis: <entryFree id="n3028" type="main" key="a^pis1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpis</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-es</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (<sense id="n3028.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">nom. sing.</hi> apis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:928" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 928</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> Fragm. 32, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:3:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 9, 3, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:12:1" default="NO">9, 12, 1</bibl>.—The form apes is given in <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 613</bibl> and 703 P., and Prob. 1470 ib. as the prevailing one, to which the <lbl>dim.</lbl> apicula is no objection, since fides also has fidicula.—The <hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> varies between -ium and -um. The form apium is found, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:16:14" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 16, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:33:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 33, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:23:3" default="NO" valid="yes">27, 23, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:46:5" default="NO" valid="yes">38, 46, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:3:3" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 9, 3, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:9:1 al" default="NO">9, 9, 1 al.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:158" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 42, 64, § 158</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:7" default="NO" valid="yes">11, 7, 7, § 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:27" default="NO" valid="yes">11, 11, 11, § 27</bibl>; 11, 16, 16, § 46; 17, 27, 44, § 255 al.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:13:7:10" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 13, 7, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:383" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 383</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:13:68" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 13, 68</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">the form apum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:46:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 46, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:10:11" default="NO" valid="yes">24, 10, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:8:1:4" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 8, 1, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:2:2" default="NO">9, 2, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> Apr. 8, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Jun. 7, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:7" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> 7</bibl>. Of the seven examples in Cicero, Ac. 2, 17, 54; 2, 38, 120; Div. 1, 33, 73; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:15:54" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> 15, 54</bibl>; Off. 1, 44, 157; Har. Resp. 12, 25 <hi rend="ital">bis</hi>, the form apium is quite certain or has preponderating MS. authority) [kindred with old Germ. Bia, Imbi; Germ. Biene, Imme; Engl. bee], <hi rend="ital">a bee</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">apis aculeus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:22:52" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 22, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sicut apes solent persequi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:1:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Deut. 1, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">examen apium,</quote> <trans><tr>a swarm of</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,021:12:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Har. Resp. 12, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">examen apum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:10:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 10, 11</bibl></cit>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,026:14:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Jud. 14, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">apes leves,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:1:49" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 1, 49</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 54</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">florilegae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:366" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 366</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">melliferae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:15:387" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 387</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">parcae,</quote> <trans><tr>frugal</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">apis sedula,</quote> <trans><tr>the busy bee</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:298" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 298</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 3, 21</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">apum reges (their sovereign being regarded by the ancients as a male),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:10:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 9, 10, 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 68</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">Attica apis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:4:30" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 5, 4, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fingunt favos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:44:157" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 44, 157</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">confingunt favos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 5, 4, § 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">condunt examina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:452" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 452</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exeunt ad opera,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 6, 5, § 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">insidunt floribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:708" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 708</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tulit collectos femine flores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:928" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 928</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mellificant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 18, 19, § 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mella faciunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:ib" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">stridunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:556" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 556</bibl></cit>.— Their habits are described in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:16" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 16</bibl> sqq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 1</bibl> sqq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 9, 2</bibl> sqq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 5</bibl> sqq.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 1, 37</bibl> sqq. al.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n3029" type="main" key="A_pis2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Āpis</orth>, <itype>is</itype> (<case>abl.</case> Apide, <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul. Nol.</author> 85</bibl>), <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)=apis</foreign>, <sense id="n3029.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the ox worshipped as a god by the Egyptians</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Apis</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:184" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 46, 71, § 184</bibl> sqq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:2:13:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 2, 13, 14</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n3030" type="main" key="Apis3" n="3"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Apis</orth> <itype>vicus</itype>, <sense id="n3030.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a harbor in Lake Mœotis</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 6, 6, § 39</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
apiscor: <entryFree id="n3031" type="main" key="a^piscor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpiscor</orth>, <itype>aptus, 3</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym>apo</etym> (class., but more rare than the compd. adipiscor; in the post-Aug. per. most freq. in Tac.), orig., <sense id="n3031.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to reach after</hi> something, <hi rend="ital">in order to take</hi>, <hi rend="ital">seize</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">get possession of</hi> it (syn.: peto, sequor, adquiro, attingo); hence, in gen., </sense><sense id="n3031.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To pursue</hi> (<hi rend="ital">with effort</hi>, <hi rend="ital">zeal</hi>, etc.): <cit><quote lang="la">sine me hominem apisci,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:5:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 5, 2, 3</bibl></cit>.—And as the result of the pursuit, </sense><sense id="n3031.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To take</hi>, <hi rend="ital">seize upon</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">etenim nullo cessabant tempore apisci Ex aliis alios avidi contagia morbi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1235" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 1235</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n3031.3" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To reach</hi>, <hi rend="ital">attain to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">get</hi>, <hi rend="ital">gain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">acquire</hi> (<hi rend="ital">by</hi> <cb n="APO" /> <hi rend="ital">effort</hi>, <hi rend="ital">trouble</hi>, etc.; cf. adipiscor), both lit. and trop.: quod ego objectans vitam bellando aptus sum, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 234, 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hereditatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 4, 1, 8</bibl></cit>: cupere aliquid apisci, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 74, 30</bibl>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl> p. 74, 23: aliquem, Sisenn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 68, 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">maris apiscendi causā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 8, 14 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: laudem, Sulp. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 5 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquid animus praegestit apisci,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 145</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">spes apiscendi summi honoris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">summa apiscendi libido,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui id flaminum apisceretur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">apiscendae potentiae properi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cujus (artis) apiscendae otium habuit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 26</bibl></cit> al.— Once in Tacitus with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> like the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">tugxa/nein tino/s</foreign>: dominationis, A. 6, 45.— <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to reach something in mind</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to perceive</hi>, <hi rend="ital">understand</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nec ratione animi quam quisquam possit apisci,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:448" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 448</bibl></cit>.!*? Apiscendus, <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Manil.</author> 3, 145</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 31</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">13, 20 al.</bibl>; cf. adipiscor.</sense></entryFree>
apium: <entryFree id="n3032" type="main" key="a^pi^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>apis</etym>, <sense id="n3032.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">parsley</hi>, esp. liked by bees; <cit><quote lang="la">an umbelliferous plant of several species (mountain-parsley, celery, etc.),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:123 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 8, 37, § 123 sq.</bibl></cit> The leaves of one species (water-parsley, our celery, the Apium graveolens, Linn.), were often used by the ancients for garlands, on account of their strong fragrance, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:6:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 6, 68</bibl> Voss., esp. in drinking-bouts: <cit><quote lang="la">vivax,</quote> <trans><tr>that long remains green</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:36:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 36, 16</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 7, 24</bibl>; 4, 11, 3 (cf. Theoc. 3, 23); <cit><quote lang="la">and, among the Greeks, given as a prize to the victors in the Isthmian and Nemean games,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:226" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 226</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:158" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 8, 46, § 158</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:226" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 226</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 74" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 74</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aplanes: <entryFree id="n3033" type="greek" key="apla^ne_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aplănēs</orth>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)planh/s</foreign>, <sense id="n3033.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">not moving about</hi>, <hi rend="ital">standing firm</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> Somn. Scip. 1, 6, 9</bibl> and 11.</sense></entryFree>
apluda: <entryFree id="n3034" type="main" key="aplu_da"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aplūda</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">appl-</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>prob. from a and pludo or plaudo, that which is beaten off</etym>. <sense id="n3034.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Chaff</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 10, 23, § 99</bibl>: non hercle apluda est hodie quam tu nequior, Naev. ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=10" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 10</bibl> Müll. (Trag. Rel. p. 23 Rib.).—</sense><sense id="n3034.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Bran</hi>: apludam edit, Auct. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:11:7:3 sq" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 11, 7, 3 sq.</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 69</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n3034.2" n="III" level="1"> Acc. to some, <hi rend="ital">a kind of drink</hi>: Sunt qui apludam sorbitionis liquidissimum putent genus, Paul. ex Fest. l. l.</sense></entryFree>
aplustre: <entryFree id="n3035" type="main" key="a_^plustre"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā^plustre</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (<case>abl.</case> aplustri, <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 769</bibl> P.; <sense id="n3035.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">nom. plur.</hi> aplustra, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:555" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 555</bibl>, and Cic. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 769</bibl> P.; <case>dat.</case> heterocl. aplustris, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:437" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 437</bibl>), = <foreign lang="greek">a)/flaston</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">the curved stern of a ship</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with its ornaments</hi> (<hi rend="ital">ribbons</hi>, <hi rend="ital">streamers</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and little flags upon a pole</hi>): fluitantia quaerere aplustra, Cic. Arat. ap. Prisc. l. l. (Orell. IV. 2, p. 522): fulgent aplustria, Caes. Germ. Arat. ap. Prisc. l. l. (v. 345 Orell.); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:3:586" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 3, 586</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:3:672" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 672</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">torquet aplustribus ignes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:422" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 422</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:10:324" default="NO">10, 324</bibl> Drak.: <cit><quote lang="la">bellorum exuviae, lorica et buccula victaeque triremis aplustre humanis majora bonis creduntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:10:136" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 10, 136</bibl></cit>, ubi v. Rupert and Mayor.</sense></entryFree>
aplysiae: <entryFree id="n3036" type="greek" key="aplysi^ae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aplysĭae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)plusi/ai</foreign>, <sense id="n3036.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an inferior kind of sponge</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:150" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 45, 69, § 150</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
apo: <entryFree id="n3037" type="main" key="a^po"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpo</orth> (or <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăpio</orth>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 19, 30</bibl>), <itype>ĕre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>cf.: <foreign lang="greek">a(/ptw</foreign>, apiscor, apex</etym>. <sense id="n3037.0" n="I. A." level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To fasten</hi>, <hi rend="ital">attach</hi>, <hi rend="ital">join</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tie to</hi> (syn.: ligo, adligo, jungo, conjungo, recto): comprehendere antiqui vinculo apere dicebant, Paul. ex Fest. s. v. apex, p. 18 Müll.; cf. apex; used only in <hi rend="ital">part. perf. pass.</hi> aptus (the <pos>P. a.</pos> <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">infra</ref></xr>): <cit><quote lang="la">uteri terrae radicibus apti,</quote> <trans><tr>fastened to the earth</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:808" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 808</bibl></cit> (Lachm., <hi rend="ital">terram</hi> and apti = adepti): <cit><quote lang="la">bracchia validis ex apta lacertis,</quote> <trans><tr>united with the strong shoulders</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:829" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 829</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gladium e lacunari setā equinā aptum demitti jussit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:21:62" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 21, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">linguam vinclis de pectore imo aptis moveri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:15" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 15</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n3037.1" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: ex aliquā re (like pendere ex aliquā re), <hi rend="ital">depending upon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">arising from</hi> (so only in Cic.): <cit><quote lang="la">rerum causae aliae ex aliis aptae et necessitate nexae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:25:70" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 25, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">honestum, ex quo aptum est officium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:18:60" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 18, 60</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:14:47" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 14, 47</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex quā re (sc. virtute) una vita omnis apta sit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 10, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">causa ex aeternis causis apta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,054:15:34" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fat. 15, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cui viro ex se apta sunt omnia, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:12:36" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 5, 12, 36</bibl></cit> (as transl. of Plat. Menex. p. 302: <foreign lang="greek">*(/otw| ga\r a)ndri\ ei)s e(auto\n a)nh/rthtai pa/nta</foreign>, etc.); cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 5, 13</bibl>.—Once also with pendere: <cit><quote lang="la">non ex verbis aptum pendere jus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:chapter=18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 18</bibl></cit>.—Also without ex: <cit><quote lang="la">vitā modicā et aptā virtute perfrui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:21:56" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 1, 21, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rudentibus apta fortuna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:14" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 5, 14</bibl></cit>, <pb n="138" /> <cb n="APO" /> 40.—</sense><sense id="n3037.2" n="II. A." level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Joined</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bound</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">tied together</hi>, <hi rend="ital">connected</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aptum conexum et colligatum significat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 234, 32</bibl></cit> (so most freq. in Lucr.): <cit><quote lang="la">conjugio corporis atque animae consistimus uniter apti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:846" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 846</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:555" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 555</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:558" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 558</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">genus ... validis aptum per viscera nervis,</quote> <trans><tr>bound together by the strong band of the sinews</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:928" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 928</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae memorare queam inter se singlariter apta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1067 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 1067 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">facilius est apta dissolvere quam dissipata conectere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:71:235" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 71, 235</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quā ex conjunctione caelum ita aptum est, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tim. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui tam certos caeli motus, tamque omnia inter se conexa et apta viderit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:38:97" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 38, 97</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:6:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 6, 2</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n3037.3" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia inter se apta et conexa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:19:53" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 4, 19, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">apta inter se et cohaerentia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D 3, 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">efficiatur aptum illud, quod fuerit antea diffiuens ac solutum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:70:233" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 70, 233</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, with <case>abl.</case>, <hi rend="ital">endowed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">furnished</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">ornamented with something</hi>: fides alma, apta pinnis, <hi rend="ital">furnished with wings</hi>, <hi rend="ital">winged</hi>, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:29:105" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 29, 105</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">stellis fulgentibus apta caeli domus,</quote> <trans><tr>the abode of heaven studded with glittering stars</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:357" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 357</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1205" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 1205</bibl>: stellis micantibus aethera fixum);
